div.p: This is a set of rules, which represent the aspects of a personal life as it is experienced in the setting. The story-lines of these lives are separated from the rule-mechanics thereof. Any situation that needs to be resolved with rules, such as conflicts, can be separated into different dimensions. These dimensions are treated individually, but also interact. This “dimensionality” avoids creating constraints in situations that should not have them from an inner-world perspective. Attributes are properties of people that can be observed by knowledgeable observers in the world, just as occupational or professional skills are. They are reasonable abstractions to be made inside the world.

All out-world rules are condensed in this chapter. Any competence in-world are abstracted on a five-star scale ★ through ★★★★★, where exceptional values may go beyond. Minutes and other units more easily measured are applied regularly, but the star scale illustrates the difference. How to turn this into numbers for out-world rule operations is detailed later.

A new type of die roll is introduced. You roll a d5 until you get a 1 and then count the number of dice that did not show up a 1. That is the same as the number of dice you actually rolled minus one. This roll is dominated by the active character, or more generally, the actor. It will generate positive numbers (or zero) and is termed the positive roll and abbreviated as p5. Example: Peter rolls 5, 3, 8, 10, 2 (in that order) on a d10. He simulates the d5 by taking the result of a d10, halving it and rounding up. He thus rolled 3, 2, 4, 5, 1, on a d5 effectively. His p5 roll would be a 4.

Of course, there is a negative roll that is associated with the passive resistance or the impediment. It is handled in the same way but the negative value is taken instead. Thus in the above example, we would take -4 as result of a negative roll; therefore we can simply denote the roll as -p5. These two numbers (from different rolls) are added. The result will be a whole number, called n5 (n for neutral). An understanding of this rule is crucial, so we elaborate by listing the probabilities involved as well as some examples.

The first row in the following table shows some of the results you can achieve when you roll a p5. The second row shows the chance that you have of moving up one point (i.e. right) at any given point. A p5 can never give a result below zero (0) and the chance to get “one more” is 80%. Note that this chance is always the same in each column. The third row gives the percentage chance that you have of achieving the result in the corresponding first row instead of using the p5 mechanic. These percentages you could use for rolling a d100 to get the same probabilities; maybe in order to reduce the number of dice to roll. All but the first two columns of this third row are approximations. The last column (with the ...) is somewhat special. It combines the “higher” results and is often called exploding in other rule systems. You could expand the table to infinity, if you wanted. While the extensions of the first and second row are quite obvious, the third may not be. It should be interpreted thus: if you roll 91-100, you need to roll again on this (third row of the) table, read of the result as before and then add 10 to the result. (For the mathematically inclined, this is a recursive definition, since it is possible that you roll 91-100 again, which forces you to roll on this table again and add 20 to the net result from the repeated application. We will see this in the examples.)

This table only considers one roll, i.e. the positive. You need to combine both into a single result in most cases. Two key observations useful in the future are: Zero (0) is the expectation value of the combined roll (n5) and five (5) for the single roll (p5). When comparing numbers directly, say skills in a duel, a level 0 skill will only break even (or win) against a level 10 skill in 10% of all cases. This is something that can be estimated in-world, and thus this rule lies at the border of in- and out-world rules.

To improve speed, several d10 may be rolled in ordered fashion. Order them according to size or alphabetical color (e.g. black, blue, green, yellow) or in any other way you can remember. With a d10 stop at 1 or 2. Computer applications that make rolling as easy as pressing a button are easy to program.

Assume you decided to use the third row of the table, then rolled a d100, and get a 24 on the positive roll. This means a result of 1. The second roll for the negative part shows a 50, which results in 3. The net result therefore is a -2.
A more exotic roll would be the sequence 96, 99, 93, 61 on the positive d100. That result would be 34 (positive only).

Using the standard method (i.e. the second row with a d5), the positive sequence on a d10 may show 3, 8, 10, 7, 9, 4, 6, 3, 10, 10, 8, 4, 2 and the negative sequence shows 3, 6, 9, 4, 4, 1. The positive result is 12 and the negative -5 with a net result of +7. If you decide that +7 is not precise enough, a roll of 3 and 5 on a d10 (each) gives are finer result of +7.35.

Active/positive and passive/negative are symmetrical. If you imagine one character stealthily evading another, the first may interpret the rolls as himself actively evading against a passive observation of the surroundings. That is, positive evasion vs. negative observation. The second may interpret the rolls as him actively scrutinizing the vicinity against a passively hiding opponent. That is, positive observation vs. negative evasion. Either way, one roll (or a set of two rolls) will determine the same outcome.

The rolls scale with difficulty. Imagine that one character is particularly strong with a certain skill, but also attempts more difficult tasks. Imagine the child character climbing the neighborhood tree and as a grown, experienced man climbing an overhanging cliff. The child's climbing bonus of 5 against a difficulty addition of 7 for the tree gives the same probability distribution as the adult's bonus of 27 against the cliff's 29. It is easily seen why.

Consider you have two skills of equal value that you want to add together. If the effect of the two skills combined is as good as a skill of n points better, we call that Row-n-Addition. This means that two people of the same skill with value x have a fair (50:50) chance of beating someone with a value x + n in that skill. Taking the maximum of two separate skill rolls is similar to a Row-5-Addition as far as the probabilities are concerned. (We will only use Row-5-Addition in these Hârn rules.) The “real” value to use when precision loss is important to you (rarely) is the math-formula 5*ln(1+exp(-d*ln(2)/5))/ln(2), where d is the difference. You can also use the automated formula right here.

When using the tables, take the two numbers and use the (positive) difference of the two in the first row, to read of a result in the second, and add this result to the bigger to get the end result. Looking at the tables, you see the reduction in effectiveness when adding smaller numbers to higher ones. Sometimes, to ease writing, we denote Row-5-Addition with +5, e.g. Row-5-Addition of 1 and 2 is written as 1 +5 2.

Many sections state effects, durations, fatigue, etc. as affected through skill use or similar. Whenever it is a multiple a 5, it can be subject to a n5 roll. Also see the Dimensions section in the Skills section.

Skills govern all physical and mental activities, such as combat and spell-casting. All skills are derived from character attributes and occupations and rated on open scale starting from zero (0) as the “default”, with only 10% reaching 10 points more. This is inentionally identical with the p5 system of rolling dice. The skill scale is open-ended (“exploding”) as the p5 roll is, but humans generally do not get scores beyond 30. Any activity can be organized as a skill.

Skill Base (SB) represents a character’s natural affinity for a skill. The SB for each skill can be calculated when necessary. It is unlikely this varies after the beginning of play. A skill is tested, when its application becomes useful or meaningful (a decision by the GM). Some skills should be predetermined, because their application is hard to avoid. Each skill entry below lists the attributes for its base. To determine an SB, the attributes are averaged. If an attribute is listed twice, it is counted twice in the calculation. Recall that attributes average around 0. If the character’s Sunsign is listed, it increases SB by the indicated number – this is not averaged, but only applied directly as part of the SB.

Mastery Level (ML) represents a character’s current competence at a specific skill; the higher the number, the more skillful. MLs may be improved in the course of play and range from 0 to 30 usually. Technically, there is no limit.

Opening Mastery Level (OML) is listed with each skill. This is the starting point for any skill ML. Many skill start at zero (0) and can immediately be improved. (in the fashion described below). If the number is negative, any improvement of the skill can only happen with a teacher. Once an ML reaches zero (0) this restriction no longer applies. Sometimes ML denotes the generic value that is constant across all situations. Bonuses and penalties may be added in concrete situations and that leads to a specific ML, sometimes called EML.

Every skill in the list has an Occupation entry. It shows a list of occupations with a percentage value each. If an occupation is listed, then the OML listed is not used, but instead the Occupation ML times the percentage listed. Multiple occupations are combined through Row-5-Addition. Example: Juryn has an SB in Dancing of 4. The occupation listing of 40 for his profession where he has level (ML) 20. Thus his OML is 20 x 40% = 8 and his starting EML is SB +5 ML = 8 +5 4 = 11.

Many skills can be divided into sub-skills or specialties; suggestions are given with some skills. Characters may select specialties at any time. The skill is then termed a group skill and included all (potential) specialties, even if unknown. The specific specialty skill is opened at the current group ML. Each specialty is developed as a separate skill. A character may declare any number of specialties, but each is a separate skill. Example: Bjorni has Sword skill at ML 14. He decides to choose Broadsword as a specialty. Sword and Broadsword are now two separate skills. Bjorni must use his current Sword skill if he uses any other sword than Browadsword.

Sometimes, only Specialties are given and the question arises, what ML in the Specialty implies on the skill group. Each specialty has a percentage value associated with it. (For a new Specialty, this must be decided upon by the GM.) Take that percentage of Specialty ML to get the group's ML. For example, a Mask/20% specialty in Woodcraft of 12 would imply a Woodcraft group score of 2.4, rounded down to 2.
Note that this section applies to ML, not OML. OML (if specialization is attempted at the outset) is as for the group skill.

ML is modified for a concrete test, because of fatigue, injury, encumbrance, or difficult (or easy) circumstance Example: a character might normally have a minimum 0 in Climbing. However, climbing an ice cliff, with a broken arm, during a blizzard is probably impossible, and the GM may feel an ML of -30 is justified. (This is roughly a 1 in 1000 chance of succeeding.) If instead she was trying to decipher an alien script (without access to some sort of comparison) the ML may be at -50. (This is roughly a 1 in 100,000 chance of succeeding.) Factors affecting ML are sometimes specified in the skill description; otherwise GM discretion applies.

When a character attempts to use a skill, n5 is rolled. Add/Subtract ML and any other modifiers the GM has noted. Some modifiers are “standard” and listed below, they will not be mentioned explicitely. The GM will have decided upon a diffculty, often called the negative part. This value is also subtracted from the roll and if the net result is not-negative, the skill has been successfully employed; if the roll is negative, the attempt has failed. For example, if a PC declares the intent to perform a gymnastic feat, the GM would instruct the player to “test Acrobatics against difficulty 15.” In cases where success or failure may not be obvious, the GM should make the roll secretly.

It is often necessary to know the degree of success or failure. The skill descriptions provide these so-called dimensions. For skills, where no appropriate success levels are provided or for newly devised skills, estimate the effects by looking at the skills most closely related.

When two characters use skills against each other, each character makes a p5 skill roll appropriate to the skill in question and the success levels are compared to give a net result. The descriptions of the two skills should match for this net result (they should obviously the negative of each other). The character with the highest success level “wins.” If both characters achieve the same success level, the “stalemate” result of zero (0) applies. If a tie is not appropriate to the situation, then decimal place may be rolled as explained in the initial section.

Penalties are subtracted from the skill roll directly (not through Row-5-Addition). To distinguish the standard penalties below, penalties assigned by the GM to reflect temporary handicaps are called Special Penalties.

Injury Penalty: Combat, and other activities, may injure a character. Each injury is rated in terms of Injury Levels: M5, S10, G15, and so on. A character with, for example, one M3 and one S8 injury, has a total of sixteen (11) Injury Levels. A character’s Injury Penalty is equal to the sum of all Injury Levels. For more details about injuries, see Combat and Physician. Usually injury penalties apply to all “physical” skills. In some cases, part of the Injury penalty can be ignored. For example, firing a bow with a injured foot is not impeded in the same manner as running.

Fatigue Penalty: Using Psionic talents or certain other activity generates Fatigue Levels. The GM may also assess Fatigue Levels for prolonged physical activity, such as when a character swims a swift river and then begins to scale a cliff without pausing to rest. In general, one Fatigue Level is assessed for one minute of strenuous physical activity. A character’s Fatigue Penalty is equal to the sum of all Fatigue Levels. Every minute of Rest allows a character to remove one Fatigue Level. Fatigue penalty applies to all skill applications.
Encumbrance Penalty: Encumbrance Penalty is given by the Endurance Skill.

Astral Penalty: Astrals of disembodied characters have a special penalty to the MLs of all skills, spells, and Psionic talents proportional to the portion of Aura they leave with the body. If 5% of Aura is left behind, Astral skills are reduced by -2, if 10% of Aura is left behind, reduce by -4, and so on. Some astral travelers prefer to leave larger portions of their Aura behind to give their body a better chance of resisting possession by an alien spirit.

Consecration Bonus: This is actually not a penalty. It is still applied directly to relevant rituals, i.e. those for a deity to whom the ground is dedicated. The bonus is equal to the consecrator's circle. Under certain circumstances, other recipes may also use this consecration bonus, for instance, Concocting an alchemical, explosive compound in a laboratory dedicated to such volatile compounds.

At various times in the course of play, the GM decides a character has earned the chance to improve a skill. Some skills may be developed by practice/study; some require training. Execute each skill roll as follows: Roll n5. If the roll is greater than current skill ML, increase skill ML by one (1); otherwise there is no increase. This may also be interpreted as a “Learning skill” roll, where everybody has an learning ML of 0 (but see below) and must match the difficulty of his current skill ML. I.e. the better you already are, the harder it is to improve. To improve playability, award 1 roll per gaming session. Natural affinity to a skill applies to learning, i.e instead of a learning ML of 0, start with SB +5 0. Use the Attribute dimension for that.

Additional rolls may be awarded by the GM for extended idle periods, for instance in a winter camp. Or the professional life of an NPC “off-screen” needs to be simulated. In those cases, award approximately 10 rolls per month.

Characters receive a bonus when being employed by a master with a higher ML. A character getting personal instruction from a teacher or employer can add the skill of the teacher to his roll but must also subtract 10 due to the difficulty in teaching. Be careful, which teacher you choose!

Sometimes forgetting or “unlearning” is called for. Such rolls are handled as if the current skill level still needed to be attained. I.e. if the level is not reached through the roll, deduct a point.

Improving Specialties is a bit more elaborate. Skills list specialties with a percentage value. This percentage value gives the part of the whole group that this specialization comprises. When the skill is improved (the skill group of all specialties) all improvement may be dedicated to the specialty instead. For example, 20% Specialty could see a possible improvement of 5 points instead of 1 for the group and a 40% Specialty a possible improvement of 2.5 points. This implies that often fractions need to be maintained, to keep a consistent situation for specialties. To actually improve a Specialty, start as if improving the group first. If the roll fails for the group, it also fails for the Specialty. But assuming it succeeded for the group, You do not simply gain the multiple of points. Instead, only 1 point is gained. For every further point to be gained from the possible improvement, a successful p5 roll must succeed against a difficulty of all points already gained this way. Any remaining fractions can be rolled as rounded to the nearest whole number or when “completed” by the next successful learning roll.

Note: If at any time the whole skill group is developed simultaneously, any specialties that already have the lowest level reached are not improved. By treating every specialty separately, continuing rolling after the lowest level is reached is possible. This will then only increase the specialty by one point, obviously.

Example: Assume Alosyn has an Acrobatics of 15 and decides to specialize in Vaults. He manages to beat 15 one day, possibly with a teacher, to learn more. Technically, he could be gaining 5 points, since Vault is a 20% specialty of Acrobatics. The first point is already “approved” for Vault/16. He then rolls p5 to see whether he can gain another point and with a 3 on his first p5, he now has Vaults/17. The second p5 roll (for the third point) is only a 1, so no benefit is obtained. The third roll is a 9, followed by a 6, which means his p5 is at least 2, which matches the two points already gained, so he is at Vault/18. The fourth roll is 3, 7, and 3 again! Thus his p5 is at least 3, which matches his three points already improved. He is now at Acrobatics/Vaults/19. In the future to improve the specialty, 19 must be reached to improve Vaults in this manner again. In all other respects he remains at Acrobatics/15.

Gladiators are at 80%, Hunter/Trappers, Mercantylers, Pilots, and Weaponcrafters at 60% for their additional Weapon proficiencies. Clerics open their church language at 60%, if the same family, and 40%, if an alien family. The church script is opened at 60%. For those religions that have a Temple Private Tongue this opens to 60%.

Attributes used as skills serve two purposes. First, it allows for the in-world attributes to become operational out-world, when rolling dice etc. Second, it allows players to improve this skill as other skills. The attribute itself serves as the SB for the skill. Since unmodified attribute use is a case often encountered, a table is provided for easy reference and common values. A side effect is that the average person turns out to have a skill value of around five (5). Values below zero are only reachible through “bad” die rolls.

Situations or skill applications can either fit to a certain skill fully or only partially. Sometimes multiple skills may apply. In any given situation, the GM will state the skills that apply and to what percentage. Then use a weighted average as skill. Example: The GM rules that performing a ballet, is 60% Acrobatics and 40% Dancing. A character with Acrobatics/13 and Dancing/9 has Ballet/11 (rounded).
Clerical Counseling is a Row-5-Addition of Rhetoric and Ritual.

For joining in Rituals, one success roll is made against a joint ML (Row-5-Addition). The normal fatigue is then accumulated by both participants. Example: Dar and Kalin jointly invoke Pyrokinesis. Dar’s ML is 23; Kalin’s is 17. Assuming no Universal Penalty, their joint ML is 23 +5 17 = 26. Both Dar and Kalin each accrue the normal Fatigue.

Multiple attackers can combine their efforts through Row-5-Addition into one. This is generally a complex topic, because modifiers need to be accommodated as they enter the game, so this is best reserved for NPCs that perform as single units. Multiple defendants are similarly added. An exception to this is mounted combat, where PC rider and horse may be acting in unison.
Dimensions are collected as common reference for the many skills that use them in more or less the same manner.

The Divine Grace ratio (Piety : Ritual) is multiple to cleric miracle results that effect the caster alone in a beneficial way. Healing, etc. Note that this ratio will usually not exceed 1.5, because rituals are tenants of a religion.

Judging the values of goods produced or performances delivered is the same for almost all skills. This is different from the commercial value, which depends on a lot of other commercial factors (market size, etc.). The rare occasion, where an ML of the actor can not be judged are at GM discretion. i.e. someone who successfully evades perception cannot be judged on this “performance” by the potentially fooled or only in the most general sense. The value in paranthesis is the range by which the estimation may be off. It is calculated from the percentage value x by the range (100% - x) to 1/(100% - x).
This dimension applies to music and dance but also to other arts. Forgery or impersonation of others is complex.

This is not a proper dimension, but a convenience section for the Row-5-Addition of an Attribute and 0. For finer grained numbers, observe that this fact. The addition can be applied to any SB, in particular for learning.

One dimension is the time (in seconds), which it takes to achieve the wound level zero on the defender. The wound level is a separate dimension. You should use trajectories. Once a (rolled) progression has reached its goal, a new skill roll is necessary. It is therefore possible to play 10 second round-based combat.

Any effects from wounds or other external influences in combat are applied immediately to pending progressions. At the actors choice it can offset the goal or the time. To prevent players from immediately aborting “bad” rolls, mandatory secret rolls by the GM can be used.

If time is fixed, a best effort attack can be made. For instance, if an opponent was downed and will get up within a few seconds and the bonus shall be used for better or worse. Since combat is a often used routine, the tables is more extensive than usual.
A case of percentage values above 100% the excess percentage can be used to assess the chance of creating knowledge in the domain. E.g. for Heraldry, creating an original design.
0: Character barely knows the domain for such knowledge exists. With some luck, he can guess whether a general topic belongs to that domain or not.
5: One of the most obvious topics has been heard of and can be applied, but without guaranteed success.
10: The basic concepts are known, the more esoteric concepts have been heard of but cannot be applied.
15: Most concepts are known and many can be applied with a high degree of certainty.
20: All concepts of the domain are known and can be applied with confidence. Only a few topics escape the grasps.
25: All of the domain is understood with ease. It is hard to find unknown territory, although it exists. Improvement of the art is possible.
30: Mastery of the subject matter as far as humanly possible. Genuine research or creation of new substance is possible.

The Quality dimension can be used when a craftsman attempts to produce an item from raw materials. The result is an added to the base value to find the new value. An item with quality less than its base is usually broken. The results obtained do not necessarily reflect market value. Just because an item has +5 quality to its base does not mean anyone will pay the difference in pence. Some finished goods may involve several stages of enhancement. Uncut gems may be enhanced by cutting and then further enhanced by mounting in a gold-based necklace. Sometimes an item’s resistance to damage is more important than how beautiful it looks. An example of this is weapon- and armour-crafting.

For NPCs the associated table can be used to estimate the number of different recipes he knows how to create. PCs should rather keep a book and start with what their master has given them. Self-made dabblers start with zero (0) and would need to do research. Recipes have a wide range of meaning, from classic cooking to tricks the character can teach to animals. It includes ritual invocations.

In general, learning a recipe is a roll with the student's ML. The student should have a quiet, dedicated space to study. The Dedicated Ground modifier can be added to the ML directly. The time cost assumes a student spends 12 hours per day (3 watches) on the task, and study is continuous until the recipe is mastered. The GM may assess penalties for interruptions in the study. Some interruptions, like illness or a crisis, may justify aborting the study entirely. Recipes have a circle rating, ranging from I - VI, or given as star rating. This is a direct numeric penalty when applying the recipe, e.g. performing the ritual. For learning it represents the difficulty, see the star-rating dimension. Now calculate the modifiers and make a Learn roll on the table below. Any result below zero (0) means the time was spent in vain. Particularly nasty GMs may let the PC learn something wrong without knowing.
Mentor: Row-5-Addition of the Mentor’s SB.
Scripture: Row-5-Addition of the Scripture value. The value is directly linked to the number of pages (see dimension above). The student must be able to read the Scripture.
This scale is used often, particularly when assessing the competence of a craftsman. This scale can be extended for the truly awesome skills.
The Time dimension assumes a 12h workday, thus the apparent jump from 12h to 2 days.

Some pre-determined skills, including their relation to occupation, their descriptions and other parameters are found here. When several listed occupations apply, use the Row-5-Addition of the Result. This does not apply to the Languages, Scripts and Musician skill group, where each time an occupation is mentioned, it indicates a separate skill. Specialties are also treated this way: as separate opening. As a convenience, a list of the used percentages is provided (rounded).

Acrobatics Skill is tested when a character attempts a gymnastic feat that is more than a simple matter of native Agility. These include vaults, somersaults, back-flips, twisting in mid-air to land on one’s feet, etc. Rising takes as many seconds as listed in that dimension and during that period the character is considered prone.

The ability to play a role. Used to determine the success of a masquerade or dramatic performance. Acting includes the ability to disguise oneself and/or to assume a false identity. This may imply possession of a repertoire of theatrical roles and character portrayals appropriate to culture.
The skill is used for multiple purposes; to avoid falling objects, weapon and missile attacks, and other situations requiring Agility. Dodge is frequently used in combat, directly as dimension.

The ability to grow crops. It determines the quality/quantity of crops produced. Results depend on land quality, weather, etc. Agriculture is also crop management ability, useful for running a farm or fief. Yield is the crop yield per year, i.e. this roll applies once per year. Different crops may be specialties. Use the Yield dimension but subtract 10 from the skill roll.

Used for the analysis and/or production of chemical or alchemical compounds. Alchemists devise (or otherwise acquire) recipes for their craft. Use of this skill requires access to the necessary equipment, texts, and materials. Use the Recipe dimension for NPCs.

The ability to domesticate, breed, and train animals. Animalcraft also includes basic veterinary medicine. Test Animalcraft when breaking or domesticating animals, and for each trick/task to be taught. The time required for various efforts is at GM discretion. More willful and older animals are harder to train, and few animals tolerate more than two hours training daily. Each species of animal can be a Specialty. Use the Recipe dimension for NPCs that may surround themselves with trained animals. Intelligence in the table means the attribute of the animal to be trained.

The ability to chart the stars, cast horoscopes, and make predictions based on astrological knowledge. Astrology includes knowledge of astronomy. The art of using astrology to make predictions is called Astromancy; it may serve as an oracle or divination skill. PCs may find it beneficial to visit an astromancer to learn the portents before undertaking a major adventure. Such efforts take several hours, at least, to prepare. The dimensions to use are Divination.

Subliminal sensitivity to the environment. Awareness may be tested when a character says something like, “I’ll look around.” It also is tested if an event occurs and the GM wishes to determine who might have noticed it, or at least have noticed that something is out of place. Awareness rolls are often made secretly by the GM. Awareness tests may be made for sleeping characters with an ML reduction of at least 10.

The ability to use hafted, edged weapons. Specialties include Battleaxe, Handaxe, Hatchet, Shorkana (throwing axe), Sickle (peasant weapon), and Warhammer. Poleaxes are treated as Polearms (a separate skill). Use the Combat dimensions.
A rare skill except among the Lia-Kavair, clergy of Naveh, and certain tribes in tropical and equatorial rain-forests. No specialties exist. Use the Combat dimensions.

The ability to use bows. Specialties include Crossbow, Hartbow (elven composite bow), Longbow, and Shortbow. Crossbows: The use of crossbows is not widespread in western Lythia. They are forbidden for military use by canon and secular law in all civilized realms, and carrying one may draw suspicion and harassment. Nevertheless, crossbows are employed by the Khuzdul, and some brigands. Only light (hand-pulled) crossbows exist. Use the Combat dimensions.

Different beverage types may be specialties. The ability to prepare alcoholic and other beverages. Used to determine the quality of brewed ale, beer, cider, etc. Basic materials are necessary. Depending on cultural background, this may include the ability to make wines and spirits. Brewing for public consumption is closely controlled by the Innkeepers Guild, although it is legal to brew for personal use. Ales do not travel well and most inns produce their own brews. Brewing uses the Recipes domain.
Determines the quality of pottery items produced. Results are limited by the quality of materials and equipment. Brewing uses the Recipes domain.

Tested when a character attempts to climb a difficult obstacle. The GM assesses a climb by the dimensions in the table. Additional modifiers should be made for slipperiness and availability of holds. If the character has climbing gear (rope and grappling hook or spikes and mallet) and can use them, increase ML. Speed is measured in feet per second. A running total of vertical progress is kept to determine when the climb is complete, and the extent of any fall. A single scale should only be rolled once, but any interruption, such as rest requires a new roll. Any negative speed result (below -5) implies a fall. Climbing speed can be increased at the price of increasing the risk. For each 5 levels of speed that are accepted as fall, increase ML by 1 point. The following falling height is evenly distributed among the attempted climbing height.

The ability to use hafted, clubbing weapons. Specialties include Club, Mace, Maul, and Morningstar. Because club weapons are omni-directional, they are easier to master than axes. Use the Combat dimensions.

Cultural, regional, or even religious specialties are possible. Determines the appeal and nutritional value of meals. Failure by 5 results in poorly-prepared and/or bad-tasting food. Failure by 10 may cause food poisoning. Use the Recipes domain.
The ability to use short-bladed weapons, mostly as secondary weapons. Specialties include Keltan (main gauche), Knife, and Taburi (throwing knife). Use the Combat dimensions.

The ability to perform various types of dance. Specialties such as folk or erotic dancing are viable. Dancing is very important in some cultures, and can be used to enhance spellcasting (see HârnMaster Magic). Dances are social interactions. Without at least visible encounters with dances, OML is -10. Use the Artistic dimension.

Legerdemain (Sleight of hand) is tested when a character attempts to perform a feat of manual dexterity without being detected by observers or victims. Examples include cutting a victim’s money-purse from behind or moving shells in a shell game. The victim oppose with Awareness to detect the attempt. If the victim is not paying attention, penalties apply. If the result is negative the legerdemain is detected. Awareness rolls may also be made for any potential witnesses. The Awareness dimension is obviously modified by the “size” of the feat. Shells or a coin are assumed for the listed penalty. The Grope dimension is the time a trick takes, but mostly for larger objects – this is a combat dimension.

The ability to produce a likeness, or to assess the artistic quality or realism of a drawing or painting. Different styles and media (such as painting, fresco, pen and ink, woodcut, etc.) may be considered specialties. Cartography is a specialty of Drawing used to produce poetic maps. The quality of a map is limited by the information available to its maker. Poetic maps are more often judged by the attractiveness of the cherubs in the margins than by their accuracy. Characters with Drawing skill may be allowed to copy their memory maps in poetic style to sell or show to other PCs. Use the Artistic dimension.

Determines success when embalming a corpse against deterioration, and when preparing a corpse for burial/cremation. The skill also includes familiarity with local rituals; since journeymen embalmers need to travel widely, this can result in quite an accumulation of knowledge. Religious and/or cultural differences may be treated as specialties. Civilized cultures take great care with their dead – embalming is a sign of respect and honor, and has serious emotional and religious overtones. Most temples use master embalmers (either bonded or free) to oversee their burial rituals. Embalming includes limited knowledge of practical Alchemy and Perfumery. Embalmers know how to make incense and soap, for example.

Load is the total weight of items carried or worn, including clothing, armour, and weapons. Total Load is recalculated as items are acquired or discarded. Encumbrance Penalty is the effect of carried weight on a character’s physical activities. It is equal to Weight carried divided by the Maximum Lift (see Strength skill) Weight times Factor dimension.

When holding breath (for more than a few seconds) Fatigue is not recovered, as is generally the case while fatigue is accumulated. Multiply the factor to the standard rate to get a factual rate. A factor of 10 means that physical activity that normally generates 1 level per minute, now does 1 every 6 second. Remember that the fatigue accrued must be used as modifier for the next time interval.

The ability to construct and maintain mills, drawbridges, siege and castle engines, and the like. This skill does not include the ability to make small, delicate mechanisms such as locks. For construction use the Recipe dimension.

Eyesight as skill cannot be improved, neither can the attribute. The resolution is in mm/m or m/km. Typical modifications are made for contrast (positive), movement (positive), distraction (negative), on the border of the visual field (negative).

Different techniques may be treated as specialties: Hook and Line, Spear-fishing, Net-fishing, etc. Some characters may want to fish with their bare hands. Conditions are assessed by the GM depending on season, locale, and equipment. Fish alone does not provide a balanced diet. With otherwise average condition the base yield is 3 mandays worth of fish. Conditions range from excellent +20 to poor -20. (Of course, fishing requires a sufficiently large body of water, capable of sustaining fish. Overfishing may imply additional penalties.) Fishing uses the Yield and (Yield) Time dimensions.
The ability to use articulated (folding/bending) weapons. Centrifugal force gives them high impact, but they are difficult to use in combat, especially in close combat. Use the Combat dimensions.

The ability to make and repair bows and arrows. Base yield is 1 bow or 12 arrows in a day, which assumes tools and materials are readily available and a 12 hour period of work per day. Use the Yield dimension.

Different cultural types may be specialties. Knowledge of myths, legends, and history. This is an oral tradition in most cultures. Successful use of the skill means the character remembers information relevant to the subject being inquired about. To avoid rolling multiple times on the table, the PC that searches his arsenal should give a “trajectory” among the two dimensions, after the GM tells him how obscure the sought story actually is. For example, Rogan is attempting to recall the name of a great hero of some common legend. 50% go to depth and 50% to breadth. Rolling a result of 0 would imply that 30% of great myths can be repeated and the GM rules that the hero’s name belongs to the important part of the myth. Thus Rogan recalls the name: Genin. Use the Knowledge dimension.

Different climate and terrain types may be specialties. Finding (vegetarian) food in the wilderness. Tested when a character looks for edible plants, etc. The GM assesses conditions depending on season and locale, and uses the table to determine the mandays of food found. Areas near civilization are likely to be between 10-20 penalty. Excellent conditions exist only in tropical rain-forests. and special places like the Shava Forest with 10 bonus. Season is highly relevant. To seek specific plants, see Herblore. For hunting meat, see Tracking. Use the Yield and (Yield) Time dimensions.

The ability to produce glassware. Appropriate tools and materials are necessary. Most people believe glassworkers use magic to create their wares. Glass is used for tableware, objects d’art, alchemical equipment, and, occasionally, for windows. It is expensive and the preserve of the wealthy. The best glass products are of elven make.
Hearing as skill cannot be improved, neither can the attribute.
-10: Rural Silence
-5: Whisper
0: Low Speech
5: Normal Speech
10: Carts, Wagons, Combat
15: Smith, Stone Quarry, Skirmish
20: Thunder

Different regional/cultural types may be specialties. The ability to recognize heraldic achievements, and to blazon (properly describe) arms and recognize achievements. The skill uses the Recipe and Knowledge dimensions. One describes the achievements a character can actively reproduce/draw, the other the recognized achievements, if seen. A 100% value means the set of all achievements the character has been in contact with. Reading a heralds’ scroll suffices. The OML is reduced to -10, if examples are mot available.

Different climate and terrain types may be specialties. The ability to find and identify individual types of plant. When trying to find and gather specific plants in the natural environment, test Herblore once per watch (four hours) of searching. ML is modified according to the plant’s rarity, seeking a plant in an inappropriate locale should reduce ML. Uses the Recipe and Knowledge dimensions. The latter dimension describes the recognized herbs, if seen. The 100% value means the set of all herbs the character has been in contact with. Reading elaborate texts suffices, but may give inaccurate interpretations in the True:False dimension. A trajectory on the two dimensions should be provided.

Determines quality of furs or hides cured, and the quality of leather goods produced. ML is modified by the quality and availability of tools and materials. Rough-curing (removing a hide from a carcass and preparing it for transport and proper tanning) can be done in the wilderness with only some crude tools. Uses the Recipes dimension.

The ability to assess and/or act effectively within a social/political situation over a period of time. Intrigue is used as a discretionary shortcut by the GM to avoid the playing out of an information-gathering process. For example, an NPC’s Intrigue might be tested when sent by a PC to gather intelligence in a town or camp.

Determines the quality of jewelry and/or fine metalwork made by the character. ML depends on the complexity of the task attempted. Materials are necessary and failure can be expensive. This skill is also used to appraise gems, fine metalwork, and/or jewelry. Uses the Recipe dimension.

Jumping is tested when a character attempts to leap for height or distance. Results assume a running start; for standing jumps, halve heights and distances. Results below 0 turn into a Fall. For each 5 levels of dimension that are also accepted as fall, increase ML by 1 point.

Each Language is a separate skill. All characters begin with at least one Native Tongue, determined by birthplace. Some characters may be bilingual. The GM will tell you the name of your native tongue(s). Clerics also know their church language. (These are not specialties.) Languages are tested only on special occasions, such as when foreigners converse. Characters are presumed to speak their native tongues at their social class level, which is well enough to make success rolls unnecessary in general. If needed, the duration of the result is a speech, a dialog, or other coherent activity. The ML of a skill using language can never exceed language ML in the tongue used.

Foreign languages may be opened in the course of play as any other skill. The table below shows the three language families spoken on/near Hârn. Living languages are shown in italic. When one language of a family is known, it is easier to learn other related languages. Orbaalese belongs to two families. Foreign tongues can be learned with languages of the same family functioning as as “teacher”.

Different cultural, religious, and regional types may be specialties. Litigants use this skill to determine which law applies to a particular situation. Enfoeffed knights use the skill to settle tenant disputes; success indicates a fair and just decision is made. If used to prepare a writ or other legal document, the skill is averaged with the appropriate Language and Script.

The ability to analyze and pick locks. Locks are rated for complexity in many publications; reduce ML by twice lock complexity (equivalently, increase lock difficulty accordingly). The skill may be used to appraise the complexity of a lock and/or to see if it is trapped. Lockcraft is averaged with Metalcraft to construct locks and other small/complex/delicate mechanisms.

The ability to charm, seduce, and give erotic pleasure. It cannot normally be improved by solitary practice, although there may be books or teachers available. The skill is used to assess the success of a seduction or sexual encounter.

The ability to cast spells of a particular convocation is a skill. There is a separate skill for each convocation (although listed as specialty above), and one for Neutral. Each Convocation has a unique Skill Base, dominated by Aura. The ML is listed below (as occupational percentage), depending on the chantry level; they apply to all convocations equally. Dimensions are available for each spell.

Convocational Sunsign Modifiers: The stars favor different convocations. The astrological modifier is given below. For a character born on a cusp (the first two or last two days of a sunsign), use the more advantageous modifier.

Used to analyze/construct stonework. Masons use Masonry averaged with Engineering to construct buildings, bridges, etc. Use the Recipe dimension. The recipes apply to building types, ranging from simple foundation work to cathedral construction and castle ramparts.
The ability to make calculations with numbers, keep books of account, and so on. An ML above 14 would imply some knowledge of geometry, etc. The skill is useful in many different fields.

Different types of metals may be specialties. Used to determine success/quality when producing commonplace metallic goods. Metalcraft is averaged with Lockcraft to construct locks, secret compartments, and other small, complex, and/or delicate mechanisms. Larger machinery is usually built by millwrights (engineers). Use the Recipe dimension.

Used to determine efficiency and/or yield when milling grain, etc. Milling is primarily a way to earn money. It is usually not a very exciting activity nor a useful skill for adventurers. The basic unit of yield is a year’s worth of grain as produced by agriculture. It assumes that a mill capable of such output is available. Use the Yield dimension.

Knowledge of geology and ability at prospecting, mineworking, and ore-refining. Prospecting is a complex issue, depending on the terrain surveyed and the minerals sought. These include mythral, gold, silver, copper, tin, lead, zinc, coal, salt, iron, and a large variety of gemstones.

Morale is a complex issue, it usually applies only to NPCs (and trained animals). The higher a result, the more likely the predetermined objectives are followed, usually a military one. The lower the result, the more self-preservation is deterministic of actions, but also instincts take over. “Freezing” in the hopes of being ignored may make sense with certain predators but not when facing Gargun. The variety of different reactions is great. See the Morale section in Combat. Berserk is meant as option, not as mandatory. The other end at -15 is mandatory. It often makes sense to keep a current level of Morale for NPCs that is deducted until it reaches a breaking point. Determine the outcome before any combat ensues to improve playability. (It should be kept secret from players.)
Rally: An influence on others' Morale is possible for the amount above 10 in the roll. Multiple positive and negative influences are added through Row-5-Additions separately to others' ML.

Humans can accelerate and decelerate as 3 m/s each second. Turning options are in parts of a full circle (centered around the direction of travel). E.g. at 3 m/s this means 60° off the direction of travel on either side per second. For the sake of playability variance in this should be suppressed, although a 20% spread (for a 10 level difference) with Agility modification could be appropriate.

A steed’s movement rate must be declared before starting to move. Effective movement is equal to its Move minus Steed Physical Penalty, then indexed in the Move table to find speed. Horses have four rates of speed: Walk/40, Trot/60, Canter/80, and Gallop/100. The number indicates the maximum speed that can be reached. All speeds are available at all riding skills, although commanding the horse to use it may prove a challenge. Horses/Steeds accelerate and decelerate at 6 m/s each second, but have the same turning options.

Fatigue is accrued at 10 points per minute (or 1 per 6 seconds) for the generated maximum sprint speed. Fractions (which cannot exceed 1) of that speed generate the corresponding fractional fatigue rate. E.g. running at half the maximum speed gives 5 points per minute (or 1 per 12 seconds). Only simple fractions are allowed.

Rotation (also while standing) takes 1 second for 360 degree revolution (Acrobatic tricks apply) for bipeds, which is modified by physical penalty and rounded off. Horses take 1 second for 90 degrees, modified and rounded in the same way.

Each of the four types of musical instrument (Strings, Drums, Winds, Bells) is a separate skill. Instruments may be a specialties. Among the most common instruments are Flute, Horn, Pipes, and Lute. The availability of musical instruments and skills depends on culture. ML is modified by instrument quality. Reading and writing of music as a Script is treated separately. Use the Artistic dimension.
A weapon skill; use the Combat dimensions.
Used to determine success at inventing and producing perfumes, soap, incense, etc. Appropriate materials are necessary. Use the Recipe dimension.

The ability to diagnose and treat medical ailments, wounds, etc.. Usually the physician first tests ML to diagnose the ailment. See the Physician chapter. Most folk have a rudimentary understanding of treating wounds and simple injuries, a physician can treat animals with a -10 penalty. See also Animalcraft skill.

When the internal system has become incapacitated due to fatigue, often from drowning, this means breathing has stopped and the lungs have potentially filled with water or another toxic substance). When this condition has changed, breathing theoretically can return to normal and resuscitation may be attempted. The Resuciation dimension is equal to the Recipe dimension in values. The value in this dimension is the number of fatigue points a physician removes immediately. Such an attempt may only be made once per subject every minute (by the same or different people). Multiple people working in concert may use Row-5-Addition.

Healing rate is used for wounds/injury. A physician designs a treatment that must continually be applied wuth a first roll. A second roll must be made during the time the physician actively applies a treatment (possibly identified by another colleague). The minimum value from these two rolls is applied during the healing process. Often the quality of medicine is another factor that comes into play, this depends on the therapy. (From the rules it follows that the difficulty for first and second roll can be increased by 5 for a combined roll.)

This skill is specific for each Deity and can only be opened at non-zero value with the proper religious background. (There is no specialties or specific sunsign.) This skill is not learned as usual but improved through righteous actions; it can decline just as fast through improper ones.

tr.td: Character knows that the religion exists but cannot separate it from other convocations.
Lip service payed to the religion and ability to separate it from other major faiths.
The main tenants are known and followed individually. Sects/heresies are not considered.
Religion is quoted often and other faiths routinely treated underhanded.
Adherent is seeking to further the religion outside of his immediate domain. Distinction between inner-religion minutiae are important.
Heresy is abhorred. Support for the religion takes precedent over other interests.
Adherent is a prophet and accepts serious consequences for following details of his faith. May invent rituals and the like.

div.p: The ability to navigate a ship. This skill is detailed in Pilots’ Almanac.
The ability to use heavy, two-handed pole-weapons. Use the Combat dimensions.

A character’s ability to withstand mental domination. Mental Conflict is a skill to resolve mental or spiritual conflict and can be referred to as a “Battle of Wills”. Characters are always aware of an attack, even if unconscious or sleeping. A fatigue rate of 1 means 1 fatigue level per minute, which is multiplied be the result in the table.
Modifiers: -5 unconscious/sleeping, +5 native spirit, +10 living, +10 willing. Conflict Types:

Possession: An alien spirit may possess a physical body by winning a mental conflict with the resident spirit. Possession is easier if the native spirit is absent (disembodied) as an astral. Reduce the ML by 1 for each 5% of Aura that is missing from the resident Aura. The losing spirit suffers Dissolution. An evicted spirit may later attempt to repossess its own body (or another) with a mental conflict. Remember that the native spirit (if any) always has +5 to ML.
Ethereal Conflict: Two ethereals meet and do battle. The losing spirit suffers dissolution.
Artifact Control: A character tries to invoke a major artifact’s powers and the artifact resists.
Benign Mind Linking: Some healers, for example, use mental linking as a way to diagnosis a patient’s ailments. The willing bonus implies an “Ignore” defense.

Dissolution: Dissolution is the scattering of a spirit’s “substance”. It reforms in p5 hours at the location of the spirit’s physical body (if it has one), otherwise in a nearby location. When the process is complete, the spirit regains consciousness, has no fatigue, and may now engage in another mental conflict.

Exorcism: A 5th Circle ritual invocation to aid a native spirit evict a possessing alien spirit. The ritual requires frequent laying on of hands and Holy Water. The effect is to increase Mental Conflict ML. See Religion.

Mental Conflict Example. The demon Karpek (ML 26) seeks to possess the Peonian priestess Larinda (ML 18). Larinda is +15 for being the native spirit and living (ML 33). Karpek rolls +9 and Larinda rolls -3, resulting in fatigue rates 1 per minute for Larinda and 6 per 10 minutes for Karpek. A few successful shock rolls later, Larinda invokes Peoni’s Mercy, a ritual invocation that could force the demon to depart. Her Fatigue at that point is (–2) and the Circle Modifier (–4), which reduces her Ritual ML to 12 and she fails the roll. The process continues. This time she fails the next Shock roll, allowing the demon its possession. Larinda's spirit is evicted and suffers dissolution. Her body now obeys the demon’s wishes. Larinda’s spirit will reform after her (spirit) injury of 4 points are healed and she may then attempt to repossess her body (+5 for being a Native Spirit) with a mental conflict. Larinda plans to use the ritual invocation Exorcism to aid her task.
All Talents are treated as separate skills. Generation of talents is explained in the Psionics chapter. If the same talent is generated multiple times, use Row-5-Addition for the skill level.

The ability to impress or persuade crowds by logic, eloquence, or charisma. This is something of a shortcut skill and discretionary. An orating PC needs to define the audience; mobs maybe stupider than individuals, but they cannot be persuaded to step off a cliff. Rhetoric ML cannot exceed the orator’s or the audience’s ML in the language being used. Rhetoric has many uses, from the apprehended thief trying to fast-talk his way out of a visit to the dungeon, to a friar explaining the mysteries of faith to a child. Rhetoric ML may be reduced or increased considering the targets' Intelligence and their best interest. A net result below 0 on any use of Rhetoric suggests the character has made a fool of himself and may have annoyed the intended target(s).

Intimidation: Intimidation is a specialty. It is used in situations where a character seeks to convince others to accept the user’s leadership and is used to establish dominance. This is useful in muggings, assaults, and making sure everyone knows who is boss and who needs to accept orders.

Diplomacy: Diplomacy is a specialty of Rhetoric that is useful for determining if a speaker is bluffing or lying, and for communication between people of different cultures. This specialty is important to heralds and other negotiators.

Riding is used to determine the ability to ride/control a steed. It is tested, whenever the rider attempts to command a steed in combat. A negative result implies a fall. For riders with less skill, an arbitrary penalty to the ML roll may be taken. This penalty is applied to the roll but also serves as falling threshold to the (unmodified) roll. Any speed beyond the maximum speed is interpreted as a jump of that distance. For example, Juryn tries to ride a mount with top speed of 40 (18 yd/s). With his skill of 0, he tries to play it safe and uses a penalty of 10. He rolls a -5, which is greater than -10, so luckily he stays on the horse, but with a -35 he only makes 5 yd/s. His cousin Jirun has a skill of 25 and needs to jump a chasm, so he pushes the horse with a +5. Rolling a 5, he has a total of 35, he is also lucky and jumps his horse for 10 (28 – 18) yards. High jumps are 1:2 compared to long jumps and include a long jump. Standing jumps of 2 yards wide or 1 yard high are automatic but must be separated by normal movement of at least 2 seconds. Riding skill rolls still apply. Consult Mounted Combat for potential injuries.

In mounted combat, a rider declares his action makes a Steed Command check by testing ML. A success will permit the command as desired (and possible). At -10 the command fails. This effects speed changes and turning, failures will have the steed continue what it did or what Morale dictates. After three successive failures, assume the steed has a mind of its own until the situation changes significantly.

Basically, an Unhorsing roll needs to be made, when the rider enters the saddle. An Unhorsing Roll is valid until the situation significantly changes. For minor changes simply adjust the existing roll. Note: A rider “stumble” generated by an Melee Attack requires an additional Unhorsing Roll. Unhorsing Rolls are made against Riding ML, modified by Physical Penalty (including any injury just received). On failure, the rider is thrown and suffers a 5 feet plus deceleration distance fall. War Saddle: Gives a bonus of two (2) to Unhorsing rolls.
The Speed dimension is Skill score - 20.

Most know something about their own religion, at least enough to attend church services without seeming too ignorant. For different religions (or if the character’s culture, social class, or family is irreligious), then OML is at -10. There is a separate skill, with its own Skill Base, for each religion. Appropriate training, divine revelation, or study materials are needed to earn development rolls. Most aspects of Ritual are dealt with in the Religion chapter. Language may be a limiting factor when the skill is used to communicate with a congregation. In the list above, attributes and sunsigns are for the rituals of the “Occupations” religion.
Baptism, Blessing, Commune, Marriage: Use the Piety Gain dimension.
Liturgy: Use the Piety Gain dimension, if the total piety (Row-5-Addition) of the congregation, subtracting the cleric’s, is higher or equal to that amount.
Awe: Use dimension of the same name.
Tongues: Add +15 Row-5-Addition to get the temporary language understanding.
Consecration: The rituals have -1 for each completed 5 minutes casting time. Such penalties for consecutive casting is removed 1 point perday.
Excommunication: Effects are reduction of Piety by 10 “unlearning” rolls; the reduction in Ritual are 5 “unlearning” rolls.

Excorcism: The mental conflict is modified by that part of the skill not used to reduce casting time, i.e. it is another result dimension. Use a trajectory as described elsewhere, i.e. a proportional relationship of dimensions.
Ground consecrated to the cleric’s deity gives: +2, to an allied deity: +1, to a neutral deity: -1, to an opposing deity: -4. Environmental modifiers are as follows.
Agrik: Fire + 2, Snow/Sea - 2
Halea: Urban + 2, Wilderness - 2
Morgath: Dark + 2, Light - 2
Naveh: Dark + 2, Light - 2
Sarajin: Snow/Sea + 2, Fire - 2
Siem: Wilderness + 2, Urban - 2

A popular art in regions influenced by Ivinian or Khuzan culture, this is the ability to divine, read portents, and cast fortunes by means of runestones or runic symbology. Use the Divination dimensions.

A script is a system for symbolizing language sounds. Languages in Lythia may be written in all Lythian scripts. Each script is treated as a separate skill. Consult the various other chapters for some in-world details on Scripts. Some scripts are more complex than others. Scripts may be developed and improved with practice and/or further training; either method requires books and/or writing media. Any written work employs a language and a script. Characters who know both may attempt to read it.

Seamanship is tested when a character attempts a difficult task having to do with the handling of a ship or boat, such as setting sails in high seas. Seamanship does not include navigational skills. The applications of Seamanship are detailed in Pilots’ Almanac.
The ability to use shields, which are just about the only defensive weapons available. Use the Combat dimensions.

Used to determine how well the character constructs a ship, boat, or its fittings. The length dimension shows the length of boats that can reasonably be built, because the construction principles are known. The applications of this skill are dealt with in Pilots’ Almanac.
A character’s ability to carry a tune. The quality of a performance may not be appreciated. A notable specialty is the Voice attribute skill. Use the Artistic dimension.

Skiing is a rare skill except among northern peoples of Lythia such as the Yarili of Ivinia. It is known by some Odivshe Shek-Pvar. The skill is primarily cross-country, but includes basic downhill skiing.
The ability to use sling-type weapons. No specialties exist. Use the Combat dimensions.
The ability to use hafted, thrusting, and staff-type weapons. Use the Combat dimensions.
Note that the skill may be improved but not the attribute. Average Healing time for 1 injury point is 2 days. Factor the above to get the actual healing rate.

Stealth is tested when a character attempts to move without being detected. The attempt presumes reasonable conditions. ML is further modified for distance to the target, available cover, etc. Awareness of potential observers is deducted from ML. i.e. added to difficulty.

Note that the skill may be improved but not the attribute. The listed weight can be lifted excluding your own body. At that point any activity is at -10. This penalty scales linearly down or up, any fraction of the weight carried also incurs the same fraction of -10 as penalty. Note that with certain penalties usually trivial activities (i.e. no roll required) become difficult, for instance not stumbling. Still without tools, activity with both hands is impossible. Freeing one hand incurs twice the penalty and assumes that the weight is liftable that way. Fatigue is accrued at the 1 point per 10 seconds for the maximum lift. Fractions (which cannot exceed 1) of that lift generate the corresponding fractional fatigue rate. E.g. lifting half the maximum weight gives 3 points per minute (or 1 per 20 seconds). Only simple fractions are allowed.

Different climate and terrain types may be specialties. The knack of surviving in the wilderness, used for outdoor activities not covered by Foraging, Tracking, or Herblore. May be used to establish the quality of a lean-to, build fires under difficult circumstances, etc. Use the Regional dimension.

Difficulty of swimming conditions is rated on the Beaufort scale. Test Swimming once for each continuous swim without rest. Any interruption requires a new roll. With a result below 0 the character starts to sink. Consider currents for speed determination. A swimmer accumulates one Fatigue Level for every minute of swimming at speed, but may rest by treading water. A resting swimmer rolls to see if they sink, but does not move (except with the current). Underwater Swimming is at half speed. When attempting to convey a conscious swimmer, apply a penalty of 5, for an unconscious person apply a penalty of 10.

If a character is in water deeper than their height, a Sink result implies the character goes down with the speed of the negative result. (I.e. -5 means going down at 0.75 ft/s.) A reroll may be attempted every second, but fatigue applies immediately. A character who can no longer hold his breath (see Endurance) and spends more (consecutive) time underwater than they can hold their breath passes out, the character’s lungs fill with water, they stop breathing, and the character will receive Drowning damage. An unconscious character removed from the water may be revived with standard physician/healing mechanisms.
The ability to use swords. Use the Combat dimensions.
The ability to use Tarot for contemplation and/or divination. Use the Divination dimension.
Used to determine the quality of textile goods produced by the character. Task complexity, quality and availability of tools and materials affect results. Use the Recipe dimension.

Throwing for accuracy is covered under Missile Combat. When throwing for distance, an “ideal” throwing object is spherical, weighs three ounces and fits comfortably in the hand. An ideal situation is one where the thrower has room to swing arms, good footing, and no distractions. Heavier objects reduce ML. When throwing with little/no attempt at accuracy, the table indicates the distance an ideal object carries. Aiming is dealt with in the Combat chapter.

The art of selecting timber from a forest, felling trees, and rough-cutting into lumber. The unit of yield is sufficient wood to build a wagon, or a wooden cottage. (The wood has to dried and prepared before it can be used by a woodcrafter. The units are simple trunks or batches of thereof.) Also note that this skill has a different yield dimension than most others.

Specialties may be creature types. The ability to detect and follow tracks. When spores are encountered, Tracking is tested to determine whether the character has detected them. Thereafter, if the tracker tries to follow a trail, additional tests are made periodically. Use the Regional dimension.

Unarmed Combat is used to punch or kick an opponent, applying hand or foot impact to determine damage. The impact of an unarmed strike may be enhanced with items such as gauntlets, spurs, etc. The skill is also used to wrestle an opponent when grappling. Use the Combat dimensions.
The making/assessing of weapons and armour. Use the Recipe dimension.
Different climate types may be specialties. The ability to predict the weather. Characters with this skill may attempt to predict the weather any time. Also use the Accuracy dimension.
The ability to use various types of whips. Use the Combat dimensions.

Used to determine the quality of a wooden item made by the character. Appropriate tools and materials are necessary, and the quality and complexity of an item affects the result. Use the Recipe dimension.

The basic distribution presented in the in-world chapter for attributes can be used to randomly generate them. They can also be a choice, depending on how the group wants to generate characters. It can also be anything inbetween, such as partly rolling, partly choosing; first rolling, then modifying; or a point based system, where good attributes are “bought” and/or “bad” attributes provide additional points to spend. For simulation purposes, the out-world values should be recorded by the players, while the characters themselves are considered to only be aware of values available in the in-world chapter. You may create veterans with these rules.
The preceding weight modifiers to Strength have not been included to the in-world chapter. They can still be used.
Height: This distribution is equivalent to rolling 6d6-15 around the average given.
Comeliness, Voice, Intelligence: These attributes can be treated numerically by rolling 3d6, with sections 3-5 / 6-8 / 9-12 / 13-15 / 16-18.

Strength, Stamina, Dexterity, Agility, Eyesight, Hearing, Smell, Aura, Will: They can all be treated as 3d6 - 10.5, with the sections 3-5 / 6-8 / 9-12 / 13-15 / 16-18 / 19-21 mapping to ★ / ★★ / ★★★ / ★★★★ / ★★★★★ / ★★★★★★. The following modifiers should be applied to keep the distributions consistent:
Stamina +2 for Khuzdul, +1 for Sindarin.
Dexterity +1 for Khuzdul, +2 for Sindarin.
Agility +2 for Sindarin, +2 for Scant, +1 for Light, -1 for Heavy, -2 for Massive.
Eyesight +2 for Sindarin, +1 for Khuzdul, +1 for Tribesmen.
Hearing +2 for Sindarin, +2 for Khuzdul, +2 for Tribesmen.
Smell +3 for Sindarin, +2 for Khuzdul, +2 for Tribesmen.
Aura +4 for Sindarin, -2 for Khuzdul, +2 for human females.
Will +3 for Khuzdul.

Psyche: For Multiple Personalties a 2nd character may be generated with new Personality Attributes (only). For disorders roll severity as p5 and treat the result as penalty to any Will test resisting an outbreak.

Each character generates a number of contacts equal to the character’s Age divided by five. These contacts are in addition to any close relatives and current work associates. The GMs decides on the details, including Relationship and Loyalty.

Although most income is spent simply to survive, veterans have accumulated some savings. Assume a veteran character has accumulated 10% of total income. For example, a bonded-master Ostler, with ten years experience has (936d x 10 years x 10%) = 936d available to spend on items or save.

An occupation resolves to 5 for each ★ that is taught. If multiple occupations are learned, they add through Row-5-Addition, when applicable. In particular, Parent Occupation may immediately added, when it is the same as vocational Occupation. Since SB factors into regular learning rolls (see Skill Improvement), the SB is also added in through Row-5-Addition.
Chandlers have three craft occupations at 5. Craft occupations are marked with asterisk (*) in the table above.
Gladiators and Hunter/Trappers have expertise in three weapons. Mercantylers, Pilots and Weaponcrafters have one weapon proficiency.

All newly created characters have five option points to open new skills or improve existing skills. Remember that most skills have a score of zero, so opening a (reasonable) skill or improving an open skill is the same. For each option point five points are added through Row-5-Addition. Successive improvement of the same skill work the same.
A veteran character receives three option points per year of experience; five years experience equals 5 x 3 = 15 OP. These points should be expended as other option points.

Every Shek-Pvar adds the stars of his Chantry and his Aura. During character creation these are his Spell Option Points. All Convocational spells cost 1 SOP per level, and all Neutral spells cost 2 SOP per level. For detailed spell descriptions, see HârnMaster Magic. Beginners cannot spend more than one third of their spell OPs to learn neutral spells.

Clerics may learn invocations by spending 20 Ritual Option Points. All invocations cost 1 ROP per Circle. Invocations specific to each religion can be found in the various deity articles. See Religion.
To initially enlist in a military unit, a character is assessed, with the following additions to an n5 roll.
+1: Good referral, Equipped for that unit, Years of military experience, High demand, Strength/Stamina ★s above ★★★, Half of Rhetoric ★s.
-1: Low demand, Years over 30, Strength/Stamina ★s below ★★★.
-4: Yeoman/LB, Archer/SB, Knight/HH (Fighting Order), Patrician/MH, Huscarl/LH, High Guard/HF, Horsebow/LH, Knight/MH (Sindarin)
-3: Yeoman/LF, Guardsman/MF, Yeoman/SB, Knight/HH (Feudal), Infantry/MF, Knight/MH (Fighting Order), Legionaire/MF, Legionaire/SB, Huscarl/MF, Low Guard/MF, Guardian/MF
-2: Guardsman/LF,, Knight/MH (Feudal), Infantry/LF, Legionaire/LF, Clansman/LF, Ranger/LF
-1: Clansman/UF, Ranger/UF
One way to determine how many talent are made for a new character, the GM secretly rolls n5 and adds Aura. For example, with a n5 roll of 0 and an Aura of 5, a character would get five talents.

Alternative, a character with at least an Aura of 10, may select or roll Psionic talents with total skill points of AUR - 10. Psionic Talents accrue Fatigue at 1 point per minute. Trance indicates a -20 to any other skills attempted during that period.
Charm: Roll attacker's skill plus Will vs defender's Will and reduce the defender’s Agility accordingly.
Disembodiment: Each time a disembodiment occurs, Telepathy and Sensitivity MLs increase by 1 point through Row-5-Addition.
Healing: Empathy: Add talent skill to physician’s skill at diagnosis, etc. Restoration: Talent skill replaces subject's Stamina in new fatigue rate. Heal: Add skill to Stamina for healing time.
Hex: Reduces the victims rolls by his talent skill level (literaly).
Medium: Knowing the “true name” bestows a bonus of +10.
Mental Bolt: Turn the skill level (randomize) into Fatigue with the victim.

Negation: Creates a field whose radius is this dimension in feet times the invoker’s 0+5Will. Any spell/talent rolls are reduced by the ML of the invoker. This is a separate dimension and can be combined with the radius. A field of less than 1 foot implodes and fails.
Pyrokinesis: No effect on entities with Aura or Ego, including the invoker. If appropriate, roll a fire attack against combustible materials.
Telekinesis: Use ML as Strength skill to lift and carry something without touching it.

Telepathy: The intended target must have a minimum Aura of 1, and is usually someone the invoker knows quite well. ML is reduced if this is not the case. If nothing about the intended target is known, besides tell-tale existence, the penalty is -30.
Transmutation: The effect lasts for up to ML hours.

Sin, Piety, & Morality: If a character acts in a manner inconsistent with their god’s morality, the GM should deduct Piety depending on the extent of the sin. Sin penalties can be imposed directly, but subtle deductions by the GM are better. The GM may also adjust a character’s Morality based upon actions over time. Characters with a Piety total that equals or exceeds their Ritual Mastery are said to have Divine Grace.

Some rituals are lay rituals as described in the Religion chapter. The may be attended by laymen to receive a benefit. Some need a priest as guidance. The following is a Piety benefit, if attended and an (individual’s) Ritual roll succeeds. The benefit is a Row-5-Addition to Piety, which is why the “negative benefit” is actually positive. (Any rituals must be relevant, of course. Individual donations of 1d for a rich merchant, for instance, do not qualify.)
Divine intervention is totally at the GMs discretion and the seemingly high chances are mostly from self-reports from faithful clerics.

A/D: Weapons give bonuses to combat skills based on their effectiveness to attack or defend. A Roundshield, for example, rated as 1/4, is poor for attacking, but excellent for defense. The ML used in combat when attacking with a weapon adds the first (A) value. The Attack ML of a Spear (A:4) at ML18 is: 18+4 = 22. The ML used in combat when defending with a weapon adds the second (D) value. HM is also directly added to ML. WQ is used as skill, not as attribute.

Rest: Fatigue gained by any conflict recovers at one Fatigue Level every minute. With dissolution, fatigue turns into injury. Note that spirits can take arbitrary injury before being destroyed and may heal forever. Only in rare cases (e.g. divine intervention) can spirits be destroyed.

Move: Use the Move skill to determine speed. Subtract 2 from Missile ML for being mounted. Subtract the speed difference in m/s between attacker and defender perpendicular to the shot direction. To avoid lengthy calculations, subtract 50% of the attacker speed instead.

Engage: Because the potential exists to attack/influence entities that come within range, each character has an Engagement Zone of 5 ft radius about him that do not extend into blocked areas. The Engagement Zone of a conscious, prone character is only half that around his body. This means a standing character is often not engaged by an adjacent prone enemy, although the prone character may be engaged by the standing character. Similarly, two adjacent prone characters often do not engage each other. Unconscious characters have no Engagement Zones (not even the space their own body occupies) but may constitute obstacles. A character may be attacked upon entering an enemy’s Engagement Zone until he leaves that zone. This entering may be active or passive. It is possible to be engaged with an arbitrary number of enemies at a time. A character with a long reach weapon has an appropriately larger engagement zone and may therfore be eligible to attack before others. This may be of importance for mounted Charges into a row of Pikemen.

Charge: Requiring a steed to halt may imply multiple attacks due to deceleration restrictions. Every engagement along the way may attack the steed/rider as usual. If the intent is to cause little damage, use the unintentional hit rules for melee (see below). Otherwise consider the group passed by to be the target and scale as per “wild” result in the missile attack section. Instead of the 60 degrees +/-2 distance, collect all in the path of 5 feet width. Any attacker plunging into defenders with an attack will decelerate at maximum rate, and that automatically determines the length of the path and the duration of the ride. At the riders discretion this can be broken down into separate attacks. If a mounted charge against moving objects is attempted, a Steed Command Check with a -10 needed the second before impact.

Push: The push attempt may range between 0 and 5 feet and must be in the direction the attacker is facing. The defender has a choice to evade into a semi-circle of up to 120 degrees, assuming no obstacles.
Rise: Use Acrobatics skill.
Grope: Use Legerdemain skill.

Melee Attack: The rider and horse may act in unison and add their combat skill per Row-5-Addition. Both accrue the same fatigue. Hitting the wrong target can happen in melee combat. Usually this is ignored, but if this ignorance is taken into account when deciding on options, such accidents shall be played out. Anybody within the range of the weapon is subject to a skill roll with a penalty of 10. This can be added to the benefit of other attackers as per multiple attacks above or resolved individually with the goal of 0 damage.

Missile Attack: For throwing arbitrary objects, use Throwing skill. Since missile attacks are resolved with individual shots, a missed attack is applied only if the intended attack had no impact. Count all potential targets completely in an arc of 60 degrees and +/-2 range levels of the intended target. Use Row-5-Addition of zeroes, but reduce by 5 for the missed, intended opponent. If a hit is scored on the much larger target, roll which target is hit by distributing evenly among all the unintended targets. When determining hit chances and damage apply the size modifier from the Size table below. At GM discretion, inanimate objects not participating in the skirmish may be counted as potential targets, particularly, if the actual targets are spread widely across the area.
