This increase can be used purposefully and can be quite devastating when firing at advancing troops. The Missile Attack table below reduces calculation for playability. Penetrating hits are ignored, i.e. no shots through multiple targets. The assumed skills rolls all use 0 damage and no personal, e.g. aiming, modifiers.
Grapple/Tangle: Use Unarmed Combat skill.
Block/Dodge: For dodging, use Dodge skill. Dodge and Block/Parry are added through Row-5-Addition, if used together.
Steed Trample: Use steed ML (and penalties) only.

Polearm Defense: Remember the Reach of Long weapons. Usually Steed Stumble Roll, followed by an Unhorsing Roll is necessary to continue a Charge into polearms (assuming the Steed Command Check was successful).

Aiming: The Attacker may declare one Main area as not being hit for a penalty of 1 to ML. This choice can be taken multiple times, but the remaining Main locations must remain (bodily) connected. If all but one Main location has been eliminated, individual percentage points may be reduced for a Detail area. This penalty can again be taken multiple times but the remaining Detail hit locations must be (bodily) connected. The GM may restrict or penalize the choice of Aiming Zone if the attacker could only reach certain target zones with the declared attack weapon. A prone attacker would find it difficult to aim high on a standing opponent. The Size table can be used, if the target is smaller than man-sized. This effect does not cummulate with aiming for parts of a target (the main part of this paragraph). There is no modification for man-sized creatures, unless the target offers a smaller effective target. A prone man, for example, presents a target about 2 feet tall, and a crouching man about 4 feet tall. Similar height adjustments may apply to other targets at GM discretion.

Outnumbered: The ML for any defense is decreased by 2 for each engaged enemy above one that is not ignored. (This includes prone enemies.) That is, a character outnumbered 3:1 subtracts 4 from ML for all defense rolls.
Prone: A character who is attacking (or being attacked by) a prone enemy increases ML by 4.

Stop: A stop from a sprint/charge faster than the maximum “natural” deceleration rate may be necessary. (Running into a wall or head on into another opponent that doesn’t dodge.) In that case consider the distance that is not available to stopping as fall. Surface is considered at 30°. This damage is taken by the steed (or the runner). An appropriate strike location should be chosen. If the obstacle is reasonably capable of taking damage apply it there too. (If desired, use physics of an inelastic collision, i.e. when running into a wagon that starts to roll when run into. Damage always applies to both.)

Fall: Acrobatics can be used to moderate a fall. All successful points on Acrobatics vs 15 can be used by the faller as in Aiming, i.e. the main and detailed body part to land on. The slope of the surface may cause a falling climber to hit several times on the way down. When this occurs, reduce damage to what the incline is as part of 90°. E.g. 30° would reduce the damage to 1/3. A character may be able to stop falling by grabbing protrusions, bushes, etc. This rarely stops the fall, but may slow it and reduce landing impact. Randomize an M1 type B wound to the hands and deduct 1 ft from the height. The wound impact can be increased up to M10 for a corresponding reduction. If so desired, the fall can be stopped at a random location and the falling damage recalculated. Damage is then aimed with +20 at the grabbing arm. This grabbing cannot be used together with Acrobatics. The character now hangs from the protrusion. Falls use the Fall table. Various surfaces modify fall impact: Water (up to 10 ft): -1 / ft. Mud, Bog: -2. Stone: +3. Uneven, Rocks: +6.

Each opponent is attacker and defender at the same time and the result is determined through normal ML rolls. Use the following tactical modifiers.

The chance for the pole to break is equal to the impact it causes (before armor reduction). The chance for a shield to break is the amount of damage is absorbs (provided it is hit). If the shield breaks, reduce strike impact by 3 further points.

If your pole does not break, your opponent may be injured. Determine Strike Location and effective impact normally. Because there is more chance of being struck on the left side of the body, roll 1d4 for strike locations with two sides: 1-3 = left; 4 = right. If the location struck is covered by a shield (see above) a shield damage check is made. If the shield does not break, it deflects the strike and there is no effective impact. Otherwise, determine injury effect as normal. Any strike, including one by a broken pole, requires an Unhorsing Roll. Also, if the strike impact exceeds the target’s STR (before armour reduction) an unhorsing roll is required.
Drowning: While incapacitated, the internal system takes 1 injury and 1 fatigue point every 6 seconds until fresh air is available.

Bloodloss: damage taken increases at Impact - 10 per 10s. For example, a 12 point injury causes 2 points per 10 seconds, or 1 point of bloodloss to accrue every 5 seconds. (A 22 destroying wound causes more than 1 point per second in bloodloss and only very unlikely circumstances will keep the victim alive for more than 15 seconds.)
Inanimate Damage: Instead of (autonomous) Healing, Repair must be applied externally. Use the appropriate Craft skill instead of Physician.
Weapon/Armor Damage: Weapon and Armour make a Shock roll for the damage that they absorb, respectively deal. This includes grappling damage. Weapon Quality (WQ) is used instead of Stamina skill.

Fumble: Any new wound of at least 1 point to arms results in a Fumble chance. Use accumulated damage to that extremity as difficulty for a Dexterity skill roll. Failure results in dropping anything held on that arm.
Stumble: Any new wound of at least 1 point to legs results in a Stumble chance. Use accumulated damage to that extremity as difficulty for an Agility skill roll. Failure results in dropping prone.
Shock: Any new wound of at least 1 point results in a Shock chance. Use accumulated injury and fatigue as difficulty for a Stamina skill roll but subtract 10. Failure results in unconsciousness.

All people are individuals that act in Hârnworld. They, particularly PCs, are at the core of what these rules are all about. Apart of the numerical attributes, a few of the only descriptive aspects should be mentioned.

Attributes are values that other people “attribute” to individuals they encounter, particularly those that they interact with for some time. The following lists those properties and the common values used for them.

Individuals should have a moral compass. Morality is a measure of unselfishness. The following serves as a guideline of the diversity found in Hârnworld, but is by no means exhaustive. Sindarin tend towards the “higher” moral standards.

Customary description of Morality include: Diabolical, Unscrupulous, Corruptible, Law-Abiding, Principled, Exemplary. They are not always applied correctly when dealing with enemies or friends. Moral description from others tend to be worse when describing an enemy.
People have a descriptive sexuality. The distribution of sexuality in Hârn is roughly 90% heterosexual, 5% bi-sexual and 5% homosexual. Other forms of sexuality may exist but are hidden.

Although Hârn has many exotic creatures, Humans, Sindarin and Khuzdul are by far the most commonly encountered. The population distribution on Hârn is approximately Human (97%), Sindarin (1%), and Khuzdul (1%).
Among encountered humans 48% are male, among Sindarin 45%, and among Khuzdul 75%. (Other individuals encountered are female.)

Every day of the year (360) has an equal probability of being the birthday of a random person. In other words: they are evenly distributed. Names of calendar months are readily available in other sections of Hârnworld.

Sunsign is a major factor for skill-affinity, but all sunsigns have advantages and disadvantages. Sunsign is determined by birthdate. The first two and last two days of each sign are termed the cusp: a person born on the 1st of Ilvin is termed a Tai-Skorus Cusp (the actual sunsign is named first). Those born on the cusp enjoy the benefits of either sign. Hârnic astrology reveals the Pvaric nature of Kelestia. Personality descriptions for each of the twelve signs of the zodiac are given in HârnPlayer. The personality of a person born on the cusp would be a blend of the two signs.
HârnWorld regional modules provide Birthplace generation tables. The GM may assign you a birthplace, or tell you what dice to roll to generate one on these tables.
A person’s Culture is determined by Birthplace. Most people born on Hârn are Feudal. Common exceptions are: Imperial (Tharda), Viking (Orbaalese), Tribal, Sindarin, and Khuzan.

The Social Class is usually not something considered random. The table shows the distribution of all classes, should a hypothetical census be taken. It may be useful to determine the Social Class of a randomly encountered individual. For some cultures a random result does not make sense (e.g. Slaves in Kaldor). Refer to the relevant HârnWorld publication.

About a third of all individuals encountered are first-born. Of the remainder, a third is a second-born and so on. For Sindarin and Khuzdul 50% are first-born and of the remainder, 50% are second-born instead. The sex and age of each sibling may be determined accordingly, with a 60% of each still being alive. To determine the number of siblings, determine the rank of the last sibling as before, but which obviously must come after the indiviual's rank already determined.
The individual’s Father and Mother represent an important aspect of an individual in a mostly feudal society.

50% of all people are regular offspring, the person is raised by his natural parents. Of these cases, when a minor comes of age, 60% see both parents alive and living together, 20% see either the father or the mother absent (desertion, divorce, etc.). In the remaining 20% either the father or mother is dead, in half of the cases the surviving spouse has remarried.

20% of all people were fostered; they lived with another family for social, economic, or political reasons. Guilded apprentices are usually fostered with their masters, as are squires training for knighthood. Poor families, especially those with only one parent, commonly foster one or more children with a relative or neighbor. Fostered children are usually aware of their parents’ identity.

5% of individuals were adopted by another family for social, economic, or political reasons. Adoption is generally only done if both parents are dead, but there are exceptions if parental consent is given. Adopted children are often unaware of the fact.

15% are Bastards. Parents never married, most likely because the father was of a higher social class, or one (or both) parents were already married or betrothed. Acknowledgement happens only in a third of all cases. A bastard usually lives with his mother, but may reside with father if acknowledged.

10% of people are orphans, both father and mother are deceased. Only 5% of orphans live alone, the others are either Fostered with another family/clan (80%) or adopted by another family/clan (15%). Brothers and sisters (if any) may have been fostered/adopted by another family.

It is the habit of the upper classes to spread their oats throughout the lower classes; if unacknowledged, the real father may never be known, but then again, he may be someone of wealth and power who could be helpful. Acknowledging a bastard is a significant act; the admission can have important emotional ramifications for both parents, especially to their respective spouses. In families where there is property and/or titles to inherit, acknowledged bastards usually follow the youngest legitimate heir, but dynamic characters may do better, especially if they happen to be a father’s eldest son and the legitimate heirs are weak. Many a dynastic bonfire has been ignited with such a spark.

Estrangement measures a person’s popularity in the clan, tribe, and/or family. It has a significant effect on opportunities, including any inheritance. Being the eldest child of a knight is less advantageous if he hates you. Siblings with different estrangements are often jealous of each other; this can produce interesting family politics.
10% are outcasts. They are ignored or may even be attacked by other family members. Of eldest children, only 5% are outcasts, and in small clans any child has only a 1% chance of being outcast.
30% are unpopular. With the likely exception of the mother, the family dislikes the person. Any birthright is/was given grudgingly, if at all. In small clans this happens only a 20% of the time.
35% are popular with their clan.
5% are treated as favorites. The individual has privileges, possibly at the expense of other siblings. Of eldest children, 10% are favorite. In small clans, 24% of offspring is treated favoringly.

A person’s relationship to the Clanhead is often more important than to parents. Hârnic clans tend to be large. Some live in close proximity. Some number in the thousands and are widely dispersed. Wealthy and noble clans are often extended. Poor clans are likely to be smaller, especially if they live in major settlements. Poor families in the same town or district may have the same clan name, but have been out of touch for generations. Except for outcast characters, the clanhead can always provide shelter and a hot meal. In some cultures, maternal relationships are more important.
The hypothetical census would have for a person: 15% father or mother as the clan head, 10% a cousin, 25% an aunt or uncle. All others (50%) identify the clanhead as distant.

The average height of a Hârnic male human is 68 inches with a variance of 5.83. The average is modified: Sindarin: -3", Khuzdul: -14". Human females: -2", Sindarin females: 1". Ivinian +1”, nobility +2”, urban poor -2”. Such measurements are often made by Physicians, while averages and variance thereof are only calculated by excentric scholars.
On Hârn, the “optimal” weight of a person depends on his height and is determined by the Physician's Guild and usually published in a yearly almanach.

The Clothiers' Guild and others have agreed on a size measure that relates to weight and is only a scale from 1-10. The apparent distribution of sizes is recorded here. Items that are too small or too big cause discomfort. A one size difference may be acceptable. The distribution was calculated on the human population alone. Non-humans were too rare, when the data was sampled, but their sizes have been standardized by the guild none-the-less. (Weight is in lbs.)

Frame is another proportional attribute mainly used by Clothiers. It is measured in five main categories. It is determined by the actual instead of the optimal weight to height ratio. The optimal Weight : Height ratio is considered 100%.
Complexion is the color of a person’s skin. Human is for all people of Hârnic ancestry. Nordic humans are similar to Khuzdul.
A person’s attractiveness to the same species. Comeliness can be modified by cosmetics, but these enhancements usually wear off after some time. The courtesan's guild maintains these statistics.

Physical ability is assessed by the military (including their physicians) and a five-star rating is used. Non-humans often have their own physiology - that is recognized in the statistics. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Agility moves the body. Agility is useful for warriors, seamen, and dancers.
Dexterity is the ability to manipulate objects with the hands. Dexterity is important for warriors and cut-purses.
Stamina is the general physiological condition. Stamina determines for how long wound healing takes and also affects disease and poison resistance.

Strength is sheer physical power, a crucial attribute for combat and other physical activities, which is why military types usually assess it. It is common knowledge that additional weight leads to increased strength. However, this has not been measured accurately and not any weight leads to an increase in strength. It is also unknown whether the same relationship to weight exists for Sindarin and Khuzdul.

Physicians collect the data for the senses, often diseases or poisons affect the senses and their origin can be determined by gauging their effects. A five-star rating is used. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Eyesight is the ability to see in daylight. Except for nocturnal creatures (like Gargun) eyesight is reduced in the dark and that affects all activity requiring vision.
Hearing is used to sense sound. This is essential for musicians.
Smell estimates sensitivity to odor and taste. This can be useful for hunting and/or tracking, and may warn of danger. Of course, in a medieval town, a keen sense of smell may well be a curse.
The pleasantness and/or volume of a person’s voice. Excellent and unearthly voices are in high demand. The scale is provided by the Sindarin.

Some people have one or more Medical Traits, or diseases, scars, and other identifying marks acquired during life. The Sindarin are immune to human diseases, but more are considered “Sterile” than other species. The list is not complete and no prevalence statistics in the populace are given.

Addiction: Individuals consume some substance like alcohol or a drug. The urge is hard to overcome in certain situations. When under the influence, people may become unconscious, injure themselves, etc.
Albinism: Pallid complexion, white hair, red eyes. Viewing bright light causes intense eye pain. Albinos sunburn very easily. Some people consider them very attractive.

Allergy: Common allergies are to pollen, hair, fur, feathers, wool, bee stings, or to foods such as eggs, milk, cereals, or shellfish. When the substance is nearby, a person suffers from sneezing, wheezing, and coughing. This results in reduced abilities until the allergy source is avoided or removed. Eating allergic foods can cause serious illness or death - consider this as poison.
Ambidextrous: can use both hands equally well.
Arm missing or deformed: Activities which require two hands (such as shooting a bow, or using a shield and weapon) are impossible.
Birthmark(s): may impact Comeliness, or indicate a special ancestry.
Dwarfism: Height is Species minimum minus 2-12 inches, with Heavy Frame.
Epilepsy: Individual may have a seizure if traumatized. Swimming and Riding should be avoided.
Ear: One ear is missing or deaf.
Eye: One eye is missing or blind. Lack of depth perception and reduced field of vision makes some activities difficult.
Gigantism: Individual height is Species maximum plus 2-12 inches, with Massive Frame.
Hemophilia: Blood clots much more slowly than normal. Females do not suffer the effect, but pass it on to their sons.
Hirsutism: Excessive body hair. Such a person may be mistaken for Gargun or were-creature.
Leg: One leg is missing or deformed. Such an individual can only move at 1/3 sprint speed with the use of a peg-leg.
Left-Handed: People with this “affliction” are likely to suffer some discrimination.
Leprosy: Body covered with sores/scabs. Pain sensitivity is reduced. Comliness is reduced. Leprosy is contagious.
Lycanthropy: The individual is a were-creature. Some Physicians consider this an imaginary disease, used by miscreants to scare gullible people.
Monochromasia: Severe color blindness. All colors are perceived as shades of gray.
Obesity: A person’s weight is 50% to 100% more than optimal.
Parasites: Worms, fleas, lice, etc. These are fairly common among the lower classes. Such individuals have special difficulties with social activity.
Poxmarks (healed): A person may bear scars from a disease such as smallpox.
Scars: Invariably reduces Comeliness.
Sterile: The person cannot have children.

Shek-Pvar and Priests collect the statistics for these attributes. They are not willingly shared, only few scholars have access to the combined treasure of these numbers. A five-star rating is used. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Intelligence is the ability to reason and articulate. Often the following descriptions are used for the star scale:
★ = Absent-minded, moronic, stupid
★★ = Forgetful, slow-witted
★★★ = Average
★★★★ = Good memory, clever
★★★★★ = Excellent memory, genius

Aura is Psionic concept. Hârnic philosophers believe that all living things have Aura and that the physical body is simply a place where the immortal spirit currently resides. High Aura indicates high psychic ability, and is the most important attribute for Psionics and magic (although Will and Intelligence are also vital).

Will encapsulates mental strength, tenacity, and patience. A person with low Will lacks confidence, panics easily, and has difficulty with tedious tasks. Those with high Will are resolute, confident, and stubborn.

Phobias, manias, and other mental disorders can be disruptive. The list of mental disorders is not comprehensive. Mental disorders of the same type may have different severities. A phobia is an irrational fear/aversion. When likely to be stimulated by an appropriate situation, a person's Will is tested to determine if the phobia can be resisted or not. If relief is impossible, the person may faint, become hysterical, go berserk, etc. A mania is an irrational fascination, obsession, or compulsion, usually to excess. An individual with Pyromania takes every opportunity to start a fire; with Hydrophobia he is unlikely to enjoy swimming, boating, etc. Severity of the disorder is, of course, relevant in the actions that are taken. Some disorders are only latent and the level of Severity is unknown. It is quite possible for someone with Acrophobia to climb a mountain with no problems, but panic sitting atop a twenty feet wall. Phobias are irrational.

The list is compiled by specialized physicians but also by Savorya Shek-Pvar. A prevalence is not given, nor is the chance of multiple disorders given. The list is considered harmful, if it were to leak into the public. Translations are available for physicians not versed in scholarly tongues but sufficient funds.

* The person may change personality in stressful situations, based on his Will. The primary personality is neurotic and totally unaware of the secondary personality. The latter, on the other hand, is aware of the primary personality and often takes desperate actions to try and overcome the neurosis of that personality.

Gods or goddesses may be worshiped (however laxly) by any person. While people may respect and acknowledge the existence of any number of deities, they usually only follow one, although it is possible to change religion. The religion a person may encounter depend on a lot of circumstances and depends on the birthplace. Available choices are presented in other Hârnworld publications, which also consider culture and social class. Most people tend to follow the deity of their parents or guardians.

While there are chivalrous worshipers of Morgath and corrupt Laranians, people tend to be more satisfied if their morals matches that of their deity. Churches and clerics, unaware of an individual’s true morality, may be fooled.

People may faithfully ascribe to two or more religions, provided the deities are not diametrically opposed. Some miscreants may try to subvert an opposing religion, but this is not faithful. Some rare people may consider themselves godless. Divine intervention is another word for miracle. However, the acts of deities should never be confused with spells, which are the acts of mages.

A simple peasant may possess little more the clothes worn, a knapsack containing their worldly possessions, credentials when appropriate, and a money-belt. Most travel afoot, but nobles require a horse. A person's wealth is largely dependent on family wealth, which is relative to social status. The census data compiled by the crowns provide the following table and shows three levels of wealth within each social class. The value given amounts to what a person is assumed to possess when becoming of age, i.e. a responsible subject of the souvereign. This wealth may be used on items from the Price List on HârnPlayer and the Weapon and Armour tables. Estrangement can also influence funds.

Squires are traditionally equipped by their lord when knighted. This includes weapons, armour, and a good steed. Family wealth above does not include this. Very few Hârnic folk own property. Rural freemen and serfs rent cottages and land from the lord. City homes are mostly owned by a few wealthy folk and rented to poorer citizens. Only established urban guildsmen can hope to buy a private home. Most rural households own a few sheep or goats, perhaps a cow. Some families raise pigs which are prolific breeders. Wealthier households own oxen and rent them for village work in exchange for food and labor. Only the wealthiest of peasants can afford to keep a bull or a horse.

Clothes should suit a person’s station. A tunic, leggings, hat, and sandals are bare essentials. Some folk wear a robe or gown instead of a tunic. Travelers normally have a knapsack containing portable tools of their trade. A weaponcrafter, for example, must own hammers and tongs, but carrying an anvil is unlikely. Nearly everyone carries some fire-making tools (tinderbox, or flint and steel) and a strip of cloth for a towel, bandage, or arm-sling. A waterskin is also essential.

Nearly everyone owns a knife or dagger. Clubs, bows, hatchets, slings, and staves are also common. Other weapons are expensive and “Bearing Arms” in HârnPlayer should be consulted. Few young adults can afford good armour. Military individuals are mostly equipped by their unit, but knights on feudal service must bring their own weapons, armour, and steed.

Proving identity can be difficult on Hârn. A travelling person should have papers to prove guild rank (if any) and/or a letter of introduction from a prominent person such as a lord of the manor, or a cleric or sheriff, etc. Many guilds issue a badge or tattoo to prove rank. The expensive weapons and armour carried by knights speak for themselves.

An occupation largely determines the skills a person learns during adolescense and the opportunities that follow, at least initially. Occupation is not necessarily a life commitment. Jobs can change during a life, although this might involve lengthy re-training. The occupations available depend mainly on Social Class, although birthplace and natural talent (attributes) may open or close some doors. Some vocations (Knight and Herald) are only available to high-born individuals; some require exceptional natural talent. Birthplace is also relevant; a person born in land-locked Kaldor may have a hard time running away to the sea.

Determining the chances for the occupation of a random individual is hard, since no such census data is available. The outcome would largely depend on Social Class, which depends on the occupation of one’s parents. Some children follow the same occupation or choose another at GM discretion. The eldest born survivor, especially if a favorite, would be expected to follow the family occupation. Later born offspring have more choice, especially if unpopular. As a reference, the occupations a person can choose in Hârnic society are listed, with average income and years of apprenticeship.

Guilded Occupations: Wages given are for Bonded Masters; room and board may also be provided. The employer would bear the additional cost of providing materials and supplies, but tools are owned by the master. A skilled mason-architect building a new castle, or an exquisite sword craftsman, could earn fees up to six times higher, but such incomes are rare. Apprentices receive room & board and sometimes get pocket money from generous masters. Journeymen receive 30-60% of a master's wages, depending on experience, plus room and board. Freemasters have variable incomes because demand for their services can vary. See: HârnPlayer, page 15.

Unguilded Occupations: Wages given are for average experienced workers; others might earn more/less depending on skills. Wages are dependent on the availability of labor. They also tend to be higher in summer and lower in winter.

Occupational rating is on the typical five-star scale. When completing an apprenticeship, a person is assumed to have advanced to ★★★ through his training. The occupation of the parent will usually convey a ★ rating. Attributes play a role in selecting a suitable profession. There are practical and common sense limits. A warrior with a sufficiently high Aura can certainly learn spells, but doing so requires years learning the mysteries and ways of magic.

People interested in a clerical career must visit a temple or abbey to be interviewed by the Master of Acolytes, or find a priest to sponsor the application. An appropriate Morality and a minimum Ritual knowledge are generally required, but a large donation to temple coffers may overcome a deficiency in talent. Acolyte training takes seven years. The church is a popular career for the second (or later) sons of nobility, or for devout characters of lesser birth. The complex mysteries of church doctrine are described in Religion.

Each church has holy scriptures written in a particular language and script: Churches teach this language and script to all Acolytes. Three churches perform their ceremonies and rituals in a private (secret) language in addition to their church language.

Newly ordained clerics start play knowing some Ritual Invocations. All Common invocations rated at Circle II are taught to clerics. Clerics may learn other invocations. Also see Religion. Clerics usually complete their training with little of material value. Acolytes are unpaid and the simple monastic life they lead in training does not encourage the accumulation of worldly goods. Newly ordained clerics typically own a wool robe, linen tunic and hose, leather sandals or boots, a dagger or staff, a simple ring denoting their status, and a purse of 6-36 pence.

Shek-Pvar belong to one of six ancient and esoteric sub-orders (convocations). Each convocation stresses on certain Pvaric principles because some conflict with others. Most Hârnic Shek-Pvar reside in Melderyn. Each convocation has its own chantries. Chantries vary in quality according to a five-star scale. The best are difficult to find and enter. A high Aura is required, but most applicants can improve their chance of acceptance if they have the right family connections, sufficient funds to bestow, or an appropriate recommendation.
Lyahvi: Wind, Magnification, Visual Illusions
Peleahn: Fireballs, Volcanos, Movement Enhancement
Jmorvi: Weapon Creation, Prospecting/Mining, Lockboxes
Fyvria: Healing, Horticulture, Necromancy, Earthquakes
Odivshe: Waves, Precipitation, Movement Reduction
Savorya: Divination, Written Works, Memory Suppression
Neutral: Counter-Magic, Interworld Travel, Energy Storage

When Mavari learn how to attune to their element, they are taught to let a small amount of Principle exist within their Aura. Attunement must be done slowly and carefully, and it takes months before sufficient Principle can reside within the Aura to allow spells to be cast. Mages refer to this Aura-resident Principle as their Foundation. With time and practice, Foundations can be increased in size to accommodate Principle from other convocations. A gifted Mavari will sometimes join a convocation in opposition to his Sunsign. This gives him an advantage when learning spells of other convocations in the future, although it will impede his early career. A Shek-Pvar Satia-Mavari departs from their chantry after five to seven years apprenticeship. Masters expect Mavari to spend the majority of their time learning spells of their own convocation.

A military career provides good weapon skills, useful social contacts, and a good opportunity for advancement in society. Of course, it might also be dangerous. Only individuals with good Strength, Stamina, and Will should consider this vocation. The sunsigns Ahnu, Angberelius, and Aralius are favored for warriors.
Unarmoured Foot [UF] Unarmoured foot are most often found in Militia formations. Such troops wear ordinary clothing and may be equipped with homemade weapons.

Light Foot [LF] Typical light footmen wear incomplete leather and are equipped with a spear, shield, and a knife or dagger. Light foot are the fundamental troop type, and form the bulk of most standing armies.
Medium Foot [MF] Medium Foot have better weapons, most likely a spear, shortsword, shield, and better armour, perhaps some scale or mail. They are nearly always better trained and more experienced.

Heavy Foot [HF] The only permanent heavy foot found on Hârn are elite High Guard units within the dwarven army of Azadmere. Heavy foot carry heavy weapons like a battleaxe and are armoured with mail & quilt.
Unarmoured Horse [UH] Lightly armed troops used primarily for intelligence gathering, courier service, and light skirmishing.

Light Horse [LH] A light cavalryman is usually equipped with a lance or spear, shield, shortsword and mostly leather armour. He can be used in the same role as unarmoured horse, or used en masse in battle.
Medium Horse [MH] Riders are well-armoured in scale/mail with a good assortment of weapons. In feudal societies, medium horsemen are invariably knights or squires.

Heavy Horse [HH] The heavy cavalryman has well-padded mail from head to foot and may have strategically located plate. He carries lance, sword, and shield, and usually other weapons as well. Heavy horsemen are almost always noble and are primarily used as shock cavalry on the battlefield.
Shortbow [SB] A light footman equipped with a shortbow, and bearing light melee weapons and a roundshield or buckler.
Longbow [LB] A light footman equipped with a longbow. Longbowmen require years of training and are quite rare. They are well paid.
Because of the pervasive military influence of the Azeryan Empire, the Azeri names for military ranks are in common use throughout Northwestern Lythia.

Five enlisted ranks are in general use. These are rarely filled by nobles, who would consider them beneath their station. Molak: the common soldier. Status and remuneration vary according to special skills and unit type. Arkalin: commands a manus of five men; himself and four Molaks. Melbrin: commands a decad of ten men; himself, one Arkalin, and eight Molaks. Molarin: commands a company of twenty men; himself, one Melbrin, two Arkalins, and sixteen Molaks. A cavalry Molarin commands a squadron. Armolarin: the most senior Molarin in a centad. He is the principal liaison between officers and men, and is often the “real” commander of a Centad.

Officers are gentlemen. A commoner rising to officer rank is also invariably knighted. There is widespread belief that leaders must be noble, although there is no law to that effect. Five officer ranks exist. Hulhurin: junior staff officer, and deputy commander of a Centad. May also command an auxiliary company. Hethrin: commander of a Centad, or a Cohort staff officer. Kurlin: senior staff officer, and deputy commander of a Cohort. Berheth: commander of a Cohort. Tharin: commander of a Legion, which has two or more Cohorts.

Light horse units have the same ranks as infantry officers, except there is no Decad command. Medium and Heavy horse units differ at Manus and Squadron level. Chalisir: any trooper in a medium or heavy horse unit. A manus will be commanded by a senior Chalisir. Kephiri: commander of a Squadron of medium or heavy horse.

Most units let individuals enlist at age 16, and discourage those over 30. Interested individuals must contact a unit. The recruiting officer will ask about the person’s background, and military experience. A recommendation from someone in the unit might be helpful, and some Knight units (including the Khuzdul High Guard) require applicants to be noble.

Having completed four years of service, soldiers may now elect to continue their military career or muster-out of the army to follow some other occupation. Guard and legionnaire units require a one year contract at the end of which a Re-enlistment Incentive may be offered to sign up for another twelve months. Irregular units have less formal contracts, most likely just a handshake or an oath, but the effect is the same.

Having completed four years of service, one may now elect to continue his military career or muster-out of the army to follow some other occupation. Guard and legionnaire units require a one year contract at the end of which a Re-enlistment Incentive may be offered to sign up for another twelve months. Irregular units have less formal contracts, most likely just a handshake or an oath, but the effect is the same.

Military wages are traditionally paid quarterly, but are listed monthly for comparison with other incomes. Considering the danger, wages are low, but armies offer various other benefits, and sometimes deliver them. These include food and shelter, and the opportunity to collect booty. The wage table gives monthly base pay. Elite units may get more, although some elite units in which men serve for honor may get less. It is not unusual for a soldier to work long stretches followed by long furloughs. Armies are generous with (unpaid) leave in peacetime. All foot units know the ranks Molak, Arkalin, Melbrin, Molarin, and Armolarin. The pay listed is for Molaks, every next rank has a pay increase of 1/4 over the previous rank on the Molak’s base. E.g. a Longbow Melbrin earns a monthly 108d. Light Horse units have the ranks Molak, Arkalin, Molarin, and Armolarin and progress 96d, 120d, 180d, and 216d. Medium and Heavy Horse units only have the ranks of Chalasir and Kephiri, of which the Kephiri earn +96d monthly over the base pay for Chalasirs.

Traditionally, a soldier may keep 2/3 of booty collected, giving 1/3 to the next highest rank, who gives 1/3 to the next highest rank, and so on. High ranking officers can get very rich with this scheme. Cash bonuses are sometimes given for long, distinguished service, or as a re-enlistment incentive. There is no typical amount, although a bonus would rarely exceed a month's pay.

Standing armies typically offer land grants to soldiers after twenty years service. Monetary pensions are rare, but “half-pay for life” might be awarded to a soldier who has distinguished himself in some way. When a soldier is maimed in the course of duty, he is discharged with a lump sum bonus rather than a pension. The amount is two to twelve months pay, depending on the nature of the injury and wealth of the unit. Few armies provide survivor benefits. A bonus of about six month's pay might be provided to a widow in exceptional cases. More commonly, the deceased's comrades will make a collection.

A cohort, ideally, consists of two centads of light foot, one of medium foot and one of light footbowmen (shortbow or longbow). In addition, there are often auxiliary units, such as companies of engineers (sappers), artillery (siege engines), light cavalry (scouts), medical, ostlers, weaponcrafters, etc. In practice a Cohort may contain from two to six Centads, each consisting of two to eight Companies. The economic realities of manning, equipping, and supporting military units have always overwhelmed the neat organizational plans of staff officers. Each centad ideally has 100 men, grouped into 5 companies, lead by a Hethrin. Each company consists of 2 decads and each decad has 2 manus.

Some states, like Azeryan, group their cohorts into legions. The ideal Azeryani legion consists of four cohorts plus various auxiliary or reserve units attached to the legion HQ. On Hârn, legions exist only in the Thardic Republic where they tend to be little more than large cohorts.

Full strength cavalry cohorts are rare. It is simply too expensive to maintain such units in peacetime. The cohort shown, which exists only in the dreams of Lord Marshals, contains one centad of regular light horse, two centads of feudal medium horse, and one centad of feudal heavy horse. From mid-spring to mid-autumn, one or two squadrons of each feudal centad might be manned by knights doing their military service. Other squadrons would be inactive until a military emergency arises. Feudal units might be virtually devoid of personnel in winter. Formally, a squadron consists of 10 riders, and is split into two manus. Most cavalry tends to be deployed in small units of squadron or centad strength and massed only for battle. There are, of course, exceptions, such as the large bodies of horse defending Shorkyne and Trierzon's borders. Imperial cavalry tends to be mostly light. Azeryan, for example, uses cavalry in a supporting role (scouts and skirmishers), as does Tharda. This is mostly due to the lack of a feudal societal class. The Azeryani do, however, hire foreign knights to serve in some special forces. Logistical problems are different for cavalry units. Auxiliary forces, weaponcrafters, ostlers, transport, engineers, and the like are all slower than cavalry, and tend to get left behind. Units, even small ones, may have their own “field households” (messes) in tow. These too, may straggle.

Healing is a widely-practiced art. Clerics of Peoni have considerable medical expertise. Nearly all lay-folk, especially in rural areas, have some understanding of herbal remedies. Most warriors know emergency treatments for battlefield wounds.

Those who practice the healing arts full-time generally belong to the Society of Physicians, a loosely-organized guild. The Society does not care much about preserving its monopoly, and makes little attempt to maintain standards. Some masters are incompetent quacks, while others are highly-skilled surgeons. However, a physician who maims or kills too many patients will soon encounter difficulties from outraged friends and relatives.

Master physicians may take on as many apprentices as they wish. There are no journeymen in the Society, nor bonded masters in the normal sense; masters may take employment as they see fit. Many masters are associated with the church of Peoni, and some dabble in the arcane arts. Most physicians confine themselves to the treatment of minor ailments. Fees vary dramatically, sometimes according to the skill brought to bear, but mostly according to reputation. Fees typically range from 3d for fairly basic first aid to 240d for “major” surgery. Medicines, provided by the Apothecaries’ Guild, and hospital care (rare) can double or triple fees.

When people get sick or wounded, they are advised to get the best first aid available, and then seek someone with a decent Physician Mastery as soon as possible. Carrying a good supply of bandages and herbal remedies is always a good idea. Hârnic doctors are far more competent than their medieval Terran colleagues. They know, for example, it’s a good idea to keep open wounds and surgical instruments as clean as possible, although they do not know why. One theory has to do with fiery, invisible elementals which can be driven off with hot water. If no doctor is available any friend can administer treatment and self-treatment is always possible (modified by Will at GM discretion).

Esoteric Medical Treatments exist. Spells: For information on magical healing, see HârnMaster Magic. Rituals: For information on divine and cleric healing, see Religion. Psionics: For information on Psionic healing, see Psionics.

Amputate: Surgical amputation is the only treatment for Grievous Frost and may be used to halt infection spreading. The afflicted body part is removed, but a new Serious or Grievous wound is created according to the operation’s success.
Bleeder: Treatment must be continued until bleeding stops. The patient may die under treatment.
Clean and Dress: Takes a few minutes and requires water and bandages.
Compress: Apply cold compress for several minutes. Herbal remedies and balms reduce swelling.
Splint: Setting bone and splinting. Takes several minutes.

Surgery: Includes cleaning and dressing the wound. Takes up to an hour. Requires sharp knives, and a needle and thread for sutures. Anesthetic is highly recommended (patients tend to struggle and whimper otherwise) and disinfectants are a good idea too. Such items may be purchased from good apothecaries and improve Treatment.
Warming: Gentle warming (blanket, healthy person’s flesh, etc.) of the injury for a few hours.

Psionic talents are native, psychic abilities some people possess, but may be unaware of. Since it requires years of practice to properly employ Psionic talents, they are within the sphere of the Guild of Arcane Lore. Those endowed may notice some of the odd effects produced by their latent Psionic abilities to ★ (one star on the five-star scale). Some learn of their ability when another person with a developed talent is able to sense and inform them of its presence. Some talents are never discovered and remain dormant forever. Individuals who wish to became a mage are more likely to be accepted as an apprentice if they have an active Psionic talent.

Psionic Talents at ★ are dormant. Anyone with a dormant talent is unaware of its existence. No conscious development of dormant talents is possible. However, exposure to powerful Psionic events or artifacts may stimulate a dormant talent. Once the talent exceeds ★, it becomes known to the person possessing it. A dormant talent may reveal its nature with Psionic Episodes. In later parts of the dormant stage, frequent Psionic episodes can lead to apprehensions that the person is insane, and may cause well-meaning observers to attempt cures or confinement. This can be awkward when the person does not know the cause of the problem.

Once a talent develops past the dormant stage, it may be developed more or less normally. The individual must meditate (not sleep!) for at least 8 hours of a day to gain new insights. Anyone with an active Psionic talent can attempt to use it at anytime, provided the person is conscious. Using Psionic talents is tiring, regardless, whether or not the attempt is successful. Fatigue can also be accumulated after a Psionic episode. Particularly stressing invocations may cause the invoker to fall unconscious and also suffers Psionic Blindness, the complete inability to use any Psionic talent, for several hours. Sometimes unpredictable and/or unanticipated results may occur when invoking a Psionic talent. Possibilities for misfires are given in the talent descriptions. Psionic episodes occur randomly but are more likely, when a talent is used often or for extended periods of time.

Medium, Prescience, and Sensitivity are talents which may be stimulated by appropriate phenomena, which is called passive triggering. Medium may be triggered by the presence of ethereals, Prescience by imminent danger, and Sensitivity by a Psionic or magical residue/effect. If the stimulus is weak, the person is less likely to be alerted. When passive triggering occurs, the owner is given minimal information. If the person wants more information, the talent must be used actively (with fatigue being a consequence).

Two people with the same Psionic talent may wish to pool their efforts in invoking the talent. This may be done if skin contact is established by grasping hands, etc. and skin contact is maintained during the time spent invoking the talent. Under unknown circumstances ritual procedure may need to be followed in order to form the necessary “fusion” between invokers. This will become known to the affected invokers instinctively.

The following talents are known by the guild. No percentages are given, because talents are too rare to gather sufficient statistics. While Psionics are more instinctive than spells, concepts such as Spellfire Timing, Modeling, Detection, Noise, and Foci, all have application.
Psionic Episodes: Brief hallucinations or illusions, headaches in nearby persons, sudden dizziness, people having bad luck or unusual clumsiness in the invoker’s presence.
Misfire: The invoker, or a random person/animal nearby, suffers the talent’s effect. Sometimes the invoker gets a severe headache instead.

A Psionic talent to influence the mind of another person (victim). The usual effect is to “freeze” the victim in place for a limited period of time. In order to invoke the talent successfully, eye contact between the invoker and the victim is necessary, but only for a momentary glance. The maximum distance at which effective eye contact can occur is approximately 10 yards. The effect remains in place until the attacker stops gazing at the victim.
Psionic Episodes: Vivid dreams of faraway people and things. Dizziness, disorientation, confusion, headaches, sleepwalking, blurred vision, or mirage-like hallucinations can also occur.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the clairvoyant. Sometimes, severe headaches that cause temporary blindness occurs.

The ability to visualize events currently occurring at a remote location. A target may sense the attention of a clairvoyant. The psychic enters a trance and after the first minute gets a clear image of some object, person, or location that he is familiar with. The image may be moving and is of the current state. Sensory perception is normal but with narrow focus on the object. Clairvoyance may be used in either of two ways: Near: The clairvoyant enters a trance to transfer their point of perception to a location. The location must be familiar to the clairvoyant. Far: The clairvoyant enters a trance sand attempts to focus on a specific, remote person or object whose location may not be known. The clairvoyant does this by visualizing the person’s face (or by describing the object). There are no range restrictions, but there is also no chance to listen or smell.
Psionic Episodes: Sleepwalking, dreams of floating through space, various “altered mental states,” Jamais vu, lightheadedness, peculiar shivers, dizziness, or a feeling of being watched.
Misfire: Extreme weakness, dizziness, disorientation, and loss of balance. Sometimes the invoker simply falls asleep.

The ability to detach the ethereal spirit from the body, which is left in a state of metabolic suspension. The disembodied spirit is referred to as an astral entity. Information about the abilities of astral entities is in Religion. It is difficult to remain in a disembodied state for long. The talent lasts for several minutes, after which the astral entity instantly returns to its body (even if it does not want to return). If the body is vacant when the astral entity returns, it reunites with its body and a Shock Roll is then made. If the body has been occupied by another ethereal while the astral entity was away, Mental Conflict occurs. Disembodiment is achieved by making one’s body very relaxed (somewhat similar to how one falls asleep). The time needed to invoke the talent is one minute.
Psionic Episodes: Emotional empathy (crying at the distress of others) and sympathy pains (someone else hurts their hand and the invoker feels the pain).
Misfire: Sometimes the healer acquires some or all of the patient’s ailments.
Talent requires skin contact between the healer and the patient (who may be the healer). Four options exist:
Empathy: An attempt to diagnose the patient's emotional state and/or physical well-being.
Restoration: An attempt to remove fatigue. Remove fatigue from the “victim” at a seemingly random rate. The fatigue is accrued by the talent user at the normal rate.
Bloodloss: An attempt to clot a single bleeding wound.
Heal: An attempt to increase the healing rate of one identified ailment or wound. No fatigue is accumulated, but it requires constant attention as a physician would need.
Psionic Episodes: The individual and/or companions have unusual spells of good (or more likely bad) luck.
Misfire: The invoker suffers the effect.

Sometimes called “the evil eye,” Hex is the ability to “curse” a victim, causing them to have bad luck. If the invoker has a part of the victim (nail parings, lock of hair, etc.) increase Mastery. Such items cannot be used more than once. At the time the talent is invoked, the maximum distance between the invoker and the intended victim depends on whether the invoker has a part of the victim. If a part is available, the maximum distance is a league. If a part is unavailable, the maximum distance is line of sight. The psychic enters a trance and after the first minute reduces the victims rolls by his talent skill level. The person may be moving.
Psionic Episodes: Very scary nightmares, the dim perception of “ghosts” here and there, a dread of graveyards, hearing voices, etc.
Misfire: Sometimes an itinerant ethereal is released into the invoker’s world. This occurs more often when such entities are hostile, violent, or in search of a body.

Ability to communicate with ethereals. Any in vicinity or whose true name is known. Mental conflict is possible. Medium is subject to passive triggering. The talent may be used in one of three ways. Each requires a trance and accumulates fatigue.
Communion: If successful, the invoker is able to clearly perceive and communicate, for some minutes, with any ethereal within earshot.
Summon: An attempt to summon an ethereal currently perceived by the invoker, or whose true name is known. This results in a Mental Conflict. Knowing the “true name” is beneficial to the talent user.

Control: An attempt to command an ethereal the invoker has summoned. Another Mental Conflict must be won. Some ethereals are beyond control. With a win, the ethereal may be commanded to perform a simple task such as answer a yes/no question truthfully within its knowledge, or dispossess a body.
Psionic Episodes: Devastating headaches, dizziness, etc. for the individual or innocent bystanders.
Misfire: The invoker, or some randomly-chosen person/animal nearby, suffers the talent’s full effect.
The ability to project a blast of mental energy at a single mind within 25 yards and line of sight.
Psionic Episodes: Spells/talents tend to go wrong in the person’s presence.
Misfire: Fairly harmless with this talent.

The invoker enters a trance for 10 seconds and if successful, creates a spherical Psionic field, centered on the invoker’s head. The field lasts for several minutes, but may be dissolved instantly by its creator. The field requires great concentration to maintain; the invoker is in a trance and limited to simple activities, like walking. Any magic or Psionics entering or within the field are affected.
Psionic Episodes: A kind of passive triggering of the sense of danger. Violent dreams and/or nightmares about loved ones dying or having severe difficulties are also common.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the invoker.

The ability to determine the “fate” of a group, person, or item. Subject to passive triggering. Any positive result makes either vision comprehensible. Prescient visions can be symbolic in nature. Folklore may be used to interpret the vision. Some clerics and divinators specialize in interpretation of prescient visions. There are two active forms:

Prescient Vision: The invoker specifies the subject of inquiry. The invoker enters a trance for one hour, during which a prescient vision occurs concerning the subject. Mastery is reduced if the subject is hidden by magic, etc. Normally, the invoker lacks control over the vision, but with ★★★★ or above, it is possible to direct the inquiry somewhat. Prescience can only reveal likely future events; the future may be altered. The trance does not cause fatigue.

Sense of Danger: An attempt to assess danger in a specific location. The invoker enters a trance for about a minute. If successful, this gives a vague feeling of danger if there are traps or lurking dangers within an area that could reasonably be reached/accessed within the time frame the trance lasts. This trance causes fatigue.
Psionic Episodes: Feelings of Jamais vu in connection with various objects are common.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the invoker, or an object held crumbles to dust.

The ability to divine information about persons by touching an object with which they have been in contact. Psychometry requires the invoker to hold the object and enter a trance for a few minutes. Psychometry is most often used to divine the age or history of an object, the identity of the object's maker or owners, magical/divine powers, etc. Another use is to determine a person’s location.

Psychometry can never be used to divine the future. It works best when queries concern the present or recent past. Mastery is reduced for inquiries in the distant past, or if knowledge of the object is magically or divinely hidden. The longer the vision lasts, the more information is obtained. A reasonable minimum is 5 minutes. (Accrues fatigue.)
Psionic Episodes: When the person is in a condition of stress, nearby objects sometimes smolder or burst into flame.
Misfire: The wrong object(s) ignite.

Raises the temperature of a combustible, inanimate object to flash point and starts a fire. The object must be within throwing range and line of sight. Time to invoke and start the fire takes a long as it takes to throw an imaginary fire to the target. It takes a bit longer when the object is chilled or wet. Once the object begins to burn, the invoker has no control over the fire. The talent may be used to warm objects to a desired temperature less than flash point, but bad results may cause ignition. The talent has no effect on intelligent beings, including the invoker.
Psionic Episodes: Shivers associated with feelings of Deja vu are common. Sometimes physical discomfort must be endured or a telepathic message intended for someone else is received.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the invoker.

Sensitivity is subject to Passive Triggering and may be used actively to scan for magical or Psionic residue/effects. Mastery may be adjusted to reflect the source and strength of any such effects. Maximum range at which a spell/artifact/talent can be detected is usually 5 yards. Sensitivity can also be used to attune to magical artifacts or effects. Once attunement is achieved, it usually lasts as long as the invoker stays within range of the artifact/effect.
Psionic Episodes: Objects move by themselves, get lost, etc.
Misfire: Objects move/teleport in odd directions and at unpredictable speeds. Sometimes an object is teleported into another world.

The invoker can move objects without physically touching them. Range and effected objects are as the eye perceives them. Teleportation is impossible. It is not possible to move part of an object, unless the parts can be separated normally, such as the tumblers of a lock. Two or more objects cannot be made to occupy the same volume of space. The object to be moved must begin and remain within 50 yards and in line of sight.
Psionic Episodes: Sharing dreams is very common. Broadcast of thought or emotion to nearby people can also occur.
Misfire: Sending a transmission to the wrong person, releasing the wrong thought and/or emotion, etc.

The power to transmit thoughts or emotions to the mind of another individual (target). Transmission range is skill level in km,, but clarity diminishes with range. The talent is invoked by concentrating on the thought/emotion for one minute. The target is specified at the time transmission is attempted; the target’s location does not need to be known by the invoker. Someone who receives an emotion will feel it – this can have an interesting effect. If a person with the Sensitivity talent is near the target or the invoker at the time of transmission, they may receive the transmission along with, or instead of, the intended target.
Psionic Episodes: Headaches and dizziness, and rare bouts of semi-translucence, especially near Barasi Points.
Misfire: Invoker may arrive at an unexpected destination, most often on Yashain.

The ability to detect and employ Barasi Points to transfer the invoker from one world to another. Objects or living entities within Skill level in inches of the invoker’s skin may also be transferred. Less skilled users often lose things on the way. Travel is ethereal, instantaneous, and takes 5 minutes in “absent mindedness”. The talent is fairly common among the older bloodlines of the Sindarin, but otherwise rare. The invoker does not necessarily know where the destination will be, although it is always a similar environment. Barasi Points are natural portals between worlds. Dozens exist throughout Kethira, although the Shava Forest on Hârn has a particularly high concentration. The environment at each end of a Barasi Point is always very similar. Unskilled users may not realize for some time they have changed locations, and may never discover they have actually changed worlds.
Psionic Episodes: Headaches, dizziness, and dreams/nightmares involving the target form.
Misfire: facial disfigurement, skin discoloration, etc.

The Psionic ability to shapechange. The target form is rarely a choice and is nearly always an animal of roughly the same size as the invoker. The invoker acquires the physical attributes of the target form, but retains his own personality attributes. The effect lasts for several hours, but this can be shortened by another transmutation use. While transformed, fatigue is not accrued, only during the change. The change process takes 5 minutes either way and has normal fatigue for Psionics.

A few scholars may argue that the gods are figments of the imaginations of men, but most Lythians believe implicitly in their existence. Hârnic society is pregnant with divine superstition. In addition to the ten major deities, hundreds of lesser semi-divine entities are worshiped by Lythians. The powers of the deities, if not infinite, are beyond the compass of mortals. Demigods, on the other hand, are closer to humankind; their imperfections and weaknesses, their attitudes and objectives, may at least be comprehended by mortals. Demigods are of two types: those who serve one of the ten great deities by choice or compulsion, and those who serve no master. They vary in strength and attitude. Some demigods are confined to specific regions by greater beings or principles, some are associated with particular peoples or institutions, and some are semi-legendary mortal heroes. A demon is simply a demigod one believes to be evil.
Most religious artifacts are constructed of materials which are associated with the church and deity.
Agrik: Lava, Obsidian, Steel, Jet.
Halea: Bells, Coins, and Jewels.
Ilvir: Animal hides, Claws, and Bone.
Larani: Ceremonial weapons, Armour, Shields, Rubies, Garnets.
Morgath: Human Skin and Bone, Ebony.
Naveh: Daggers, Skulls, Onyx.
Peoni: Bloodstones, Emeralds, preserved Glowers.
Sarajin: Amber, Fur, Leather.
Save-K’nor: Tomes, Quills, Lanterns, Pearls (especially Black Pearls).
Siem: Wood, Marble, Star-shaped Items, etc.

Each of the ten major deities have mortal adherents who have created religious institutions to regulate and foster their version of the truth. The organization of churches vary greatly. Each is detailed in the separate deity articles, but a few generalities can be made. All churches have a clergy and laity although a few, like the Church of Naveh, almost totally ignore the latter. Some laity may be extremely pious, but they will not be taught the higher rituals of the church. The clergy are the priests and priestesses, those who organize and administer the temples and devote their lives to serving the deity. Although often simple folk by birth, clerics enjoy a privileged social status between that of guildsmen and the nobility. All churches of the ten major deities have ceremonial levels of knowledge called Circles of Command. Most churches have seven Circles, although those without Pontiffs have only six. The table below indicates offices a member of that Circle is qualified to hold.

Those baptized in a faith are automatically I. Circle. Those entering the church as a career are admitted to the II. Circle. Clerics are admitted to the III. Circle when they are ordained. Admission to higher Circles require approval of at least three existing members of the desired Circle. This may occur soon, or it can be delayed by years of political intrigue. Churches appoint members of the clergy to permanent or temporary offices. All promotions are controlled by those with higher office, except the highest office is usually the result of election by peers. In some churches the offices of Archbishop, Primate, and Pontiff are (effectively) restricted to clerics of noble blood. People may apply for appointment to any vacant church office for which their current Circle qualifies them. Appointments are handled solely at GM discretion; a candidate’s Intrigue and Social Class are always significant.

Most churches contain one or more clerical orders and most clerics are members of a specific order. The lay followers of a deity are not required to join any particular clerical order, but those with martial skill often belong to fighting orders which are sponsored by various clerical orders. Clerical and fighting orders have their own hierarchies. Morality is a crucial attribute for clerics. Although church officials may be unaware of a person’s true Morality, deities are not so easily fooled. Clerics entering a church for which their Morality is inappropriate are unlikely to prosper, or even live very long. Circles are ceremonial ranks, whereas offices are political ranks. Higher circles are evidence of a certain level of knowledge, but in no way guarantee promotion to higher office. A High Priest is a member of at least the IV. Circle, but most members of the IV. Circle are simple priests. Although rare, there have been cases where a VII. Circle pontiff retired to end his days as a simple abbey priest.

Legally recognized churches have the right to hold their own courts and administer justice for a variety of religious crimes, including blasphemy, heresy, and witchcraft. Temple courts often use trial by ordeal to determine guilt or innocence. The penalties handed out vary from one church to another; Peonian courts rarely inflict permanent harm on offenders, but Agrikan courts are fond of burning at the stake. Temple courts must obtain secular consent to any death penalties, a formality often ignored by some churches. For more information, see HârnPlayer.

There is corruption in every church. Most churches argue that their clerics are infallible, but corrupt ones will be punished in the afterlife. This may be of small comfort to a cleric who is roasted alive on false charges of heresy. The piety and ritual rules allow clerics to perform ritual invocations without piety, although pious priests can do them better.

The fragmentation of the churches resulting from pantheism weakens their universal influence, but their power in specific regions, or among some economic groups is significant. The churches of Larani and Peoni dominate in the kingdoms of Chybisa, Kaldor, Kanday, and Melderyn. The church of Agrik is prominent in the Kingdom of Rethem. Adherents of Save-K’nor tend to be scholars with influence throughout Hârn, on Melderyn in particular. Sarajinism is the dominant faith of the Ivinian conquerors of Orbaal, while Ilvir holds some sway among their subject Jarin. Siem is primarily worshiped by the Khuzdul and Sindarin, although each race tends to focus their faith through one of two demigod servants. Halea has support from merchants and guildsmen in all states, but is most dominant in the Thardic Republic. The churches of Morgath and Naveh have few adherents; both are proscribed and covert throughout most of Hârn, except the Church of Morgathm which has enormous influence in Golotha, the principal city of Rethem.

Piety is a unit of favor with a deity and religious zeal. People accrue Piety by performing actions publicly beneficial to their deity. They expend them by publicly committing a sin. Piety may also be used to increase the Mastery of any skill of Prayer. Piety is dedicated to a single deity. Individuals can, if they wish, maintain separate Piety totals for two or more deities. Multiple worship is rare, especially among clerics. Most folk fear this will compromise the passage of their soul when they die. Remember that a major sin to Larani, might be viewed by Agrik as commendable. Also remember that the viewpoint of a church and its deity may differ; an overzealous or corrupt priest might declare an action to be a major sin, but a deity might not agree. Adherents of churches that hear confessions may be able to avoid some penalties, but penances are often imposed, especially on ordained clerics. Some people are said to have Divine Grace. Divine Grace has the following important effects:

Individuals with Divine Grace are deemed “worthy” of divine aid, and individuals without Divine Grace are “unworthy.” Hence, a call for divine intervention is more likely to succeed for those with Divine Grace. Invocations that heal injuries, cure diseases, remove curses, etc., have a Special Bonus if the subject has Divine Grace. A person without Divine Grace will have difficulty convincing a deity to claim his spirit when he dies, forcing it to wonder the worlds as a shade, or to negotiate with another deity for acceptance.
Prayer. One uninterrupted hour of prayer and/or meditation in an appropriate temple or on other consecrated ground.

Fasting. A full day (24 hours) of fasting, which cannot include any other activity except prayer, sleep, etc. Note: starving is not fasting; individuals must make a conscious decision not to eat when food is available.

Confession. The churches of Halea, Larani, Morgath, Naveh, Peoni, and Save-K’nor hear confessions. Only confessions of “significant guilt” are worthy of piety. Confessions must be made to an ordained cleric who (80% chance) may demand a penance.
Daily Mass. Attendance at the daily church service held by most temples. Daily Mass is generally held in the early evening and lasts one or more hours. Services may be attended by anyone.
Monthly Low Mass. Most churches hold a special monthly Low Mass for the laity. The day varies by church. There is no Daily Mass on this day.
Monthly High Mass. Most churches hold a monthly High Mass which may be attended only by the clergy. The day varies by church; most have one day a month they consider more holy than any other.

Feast Mass. Held yearly on the principal holy day, this mass often lasts four hours. It is usually followed by second service open only to clerics. There is no High Mass or Daily Mass on this day. A “feaster” is a name given to adherents who attend only the Feast Mass – it is a derogatory term.

Temple Service. Some people perform a minor task for the temple, such as cleaning out the storerooms or latrines. The service usually takes a couple of days to perform. Piety accrual is on completion and may vary with the difficulty (or unpleasantness) of the task.

Donation/Sacrifice. People may make donations to temples or sacrifices to their deity. A sacrifice must be appropriate to the deity. Siem, for example, would cast out anyone who sacrificed a life; Morgath would be very pleased. Something of high value to the individual will probably be more favored by the deity.
Quest. Adherent agrees to perform a task in the service of a church and/or deity. Individuals who willingly abandon the task before completion lose piety.

Pilgrimage. Adherent undertakes a journey to a holy site of the deity. Piety granted reflects the distance and danger involved. Because the ways of deities are incomprehensible to mortals, the piety for any act may seem random.

The motives of the gods vary. The kind of universe desired by Morgath, the Lord of Chaos, is different from that wanted by Peoni, the gentle patron of healing. The problem all ten gods face is that they cannot destroy each other without risking all their destructions. Hence, the Concordat limits the actions that may be taken. Conflict between the gods is now more or less confined to the mortal and semi-mortal planes of Kethira and Yashain. Siem has withdrawn to the Blessed Realm, and Ilvir broods alone at Araka-Kalai. Halea, Naveh, Save-K’nor, and Sarajin have established their neutrality, although each favors varying degrees of order and chaos. Peoni is effectively a non-combatant. Larani stands, essentially alone, against Morgath and Agrik. These two evil deities have not formed an alliance, but it is their works that Larani tries to undo. These divisions are not simply based on morality. The quasi-war between Larani and the dark pair is more complex than a simple epic. Agrik, and especially Morgath, represent a degree of chaos, a breaking down of order that would greatly change the worlds. To prevent total chaos, and enforce the Concordat, the other gods support Larani to survive, but not to win. To prevent all-out war, there is a Concordat limiting the interference of deities in the affairs of lesser beings. Although mortals cannot know the truth or nature of these limits, the following principles, hotly debated by theologians, have evolved to justify the limitations of the gods. These principles are not always followed precisely by the deities, are often violated by demigods, and certainly do not apply to mortal adherents.
Principle of Ineluctability: A mortal mind cannot comprehend divine purpose.
Principle of Transpotence: Since there is more than one deity, and lethal conflict between them is possible, the deities are not omnipotent.
Principle of Preservation: The gods cannot initiate any action that might result in the destruction of the All.
Principle of Reaction: Every intervention can be countered by a morally-opposing deity.
Principle of Proxy: The gods cannot act directly against one another, only through the conflict of demigods and mortals.
Principle of Faith: The gods are reluctant to prove their existence, and use natural force whenever possible to explain their acts.
Principle of Interference: Deities do not take direct action against the adherents of another deity. Deities rather preserve their own adherents than to harm those of another deity.
Principle of Piety: Intervention cannot occur unless requested by an adherent.
Principle of Revelation: Deities cannot give unearned knowledge to their adherents.
Principle of Force: The gods always employ the minimum force necessary for an intervention.
Principle of Self-Interest: Deities are never obliged to act against their own interests.
Principle of Temporal Integrity: No deity may modify the past.

Divine Intervention is an attempt to enlist the aid of a deity to perform a miracle. Interventions are implemented by gods; if they choose to respond at all, they decide what to do. A deity may be open to suggestion, but will not take kindly to demands. A person may call for Divine Intervention at any time. A call for intervention may be anything from, “Please help us out of this terrible mess” to “Please tell me the contents of this box.” There are no limits, just consequences. An individual calling for Divine Intervention must have at least ★ Piety for that deity. Each deity has a base chance of 20% to intervene. (These statistics are collected by the individual churches and are highly subjective and significantly favor their own deity. Still, the average across all ten major deities is presented. The data should therefore be taken with a pound of salt.) Piety from two or more individuals may be combined; each may make a separate call. Calls that are trivial or unethical (for that deity) are always unworthy. Conversely, a call to do something the deity would probably want anyway is more likely to succeed and worthy. Note: Ritual skill plays no part in Divine Intervention. A pious layman has more chance of Divine Intervention than an impious cleric of high ritual. Deities are averse to leaving direct evidence of their actions or even of their existence. When a deity intervenes, it is generally impossible to prove an intervention has actually occurred. Virtually any intervention can be explained away as just as coincidence, the normal workings of nature, etc.

If the call for intervention succeeds, a 60% chance is estimated for the deity to impose conditions for the aid. The caller is given a task to fulfill in exchange for the intervention. Such tasks vary from minor services that must be undertaken within a year. Any condition and non-compliance penalty depend on the deity, the importance of the intervention, and so on. Refusal to fulfill a Condition is unwise.

If the call for intervention fails, a 20% chance is estimated to see if the deity exacts some kind of Retribution on the caller. If a retribution occurs the deity not only fails to help, but also inflicts some curse or penance.

A call to a demigod increases the chance of Intervention by 10, but also increases the chance of Conditions by 20, or the chance of Retribution by 10. Individuals may pray in the hope of gaining the favor of their deity for any endeavor. Prayers take between one second and one minute usually. The effect is to increase the Mastery in some skill by a few points. Success varies with time and piety involved.

Between this world (Kethira) and the next (Yashain) stands a shadowy “half world” known by many names, but most often as the Astral Plane or the Spirit World. Ethereals are spiritual entities, capable of existing on this Astral Plane, and moving between it and Kethira or Yashain. Kethira, Yashain, and the Astral Plane all exist in the same or nearby physical space. Passing through solid objects by an Ethereal is called “frooshing.” For many ethereals, this is unpleasant and/or tiring. A corporeal creature “frooshed” by an ethereal usually experiences an eerie, shivering sensation.

Astrals. An astral is a disembodied spirit, typically created by the use of the Disembodiment Psionic talent or the Transcendence ritual invocation. An astral maintains strong empathy with its own body because it must leave at least a portion of its Aura behind to avoid death. Because of this link, an astral entity always knows the distance and direction to its native body, and is always aware of any in the status of that body. A vacated body is comatose in a state of metabolic suspension. The body is subject to normal physical injury and can die during the absence of its astral. Should this occur, the resident and astral portions of Aura will immediately dissolute and reform as one entity in double the normal time. An astral may return and repossess its own (living) body without difficulty, but fatigue is accumulated in the ethereal state. An astral may also return to find its body has been possessed by an alien spirit.

Shades (Ghosts). A shade is created when: The physical body of an astral traveler dies; a person dies without Divine Grace and the spirit is unclaimed by any of the gods; a person dies in circumstances which require a “great wrong” to be righted before the spirit can “rest.” A shade may wander the world(s), but most often haunts the scene of its death until the “great wrong” is righted, or they are admitted to an afterlife by one of the gods.

Natural Ethereals. These are entities whose natural state is ethereal. They originate on the Astral Plane, most often by powerful sorcery or divine will, but may have a physical form on some other plane. Divine and semi-divine entities are natural ethereals, as are most elementals.
