Some entities are able to de-materialize their physical bodies and become entirely ethereal by an act of will, or by arcane means. De-materialization has the advantage of avoiding the risks of leaving a body behind while the spirit travels. This ability is evidence for the view, held by many scholars, that the mortal body is simply a convenient physical manifestation of the immortal Aura. This theory, if true, means that all creatures are really natural ethereals because their immortal state is ethereal.

Although usually referred to in the singular, the Astral Plane is really an almost infinite number of shifting and overlapping planes. Although movement between astral planes is almost instantaneous, only divine entities can hope to navigate this “ethereal maze” with any degree of speed or accuracy.

Ethereals have no physical attributes and cannot see, hear, smell, touch, or taste things in a physical sense. They possess only non-physical attributes and abilities, including spells and invocations. Ethereals have the Psionic talents of Telepathy and Sensitivity. They are able to directly perceive and communicate with each other, and with a corporeal entity bearing these talents. Their sensitivity to Aura also allows them to view all living things as a hazy image, day or night. When moving on the same plane, astrals and shades travel as a fast runner would and pass through solid objects at will - which is fortunate since they cannot see any Aura-less objects. Natural ethereals, especially if winged, can generally move faster than this.

Ethereals are not subject to physical fatigue, but may accrue mental fatigue by using spells or Psionic talents. An ethereal may only use talents or spells which do not involve physical action on its part. All Masteries while disembodied are subject to fatigue. Ethereals cannot be destroyed. They are immune to injury except when inflicted by enchanted weapons, magic, Psionic talents, or divine intervention. If subjected to esoteric harm, injury is translated into fatigue. Ethereals cannot recover fatigue except by dissolution. Dissolution is the scattering of an ethereal’s “substance.” It reforms in several hours at the location of the ethereal’s physical body (if it has one), otherwise in a random location or plane. When the process is complete, the ethereal regains consciousness and has no fatigue.

The natural state of ethereals is invisible. They can become translucent at will, but doing so accrues normal Fatigue per minute. This accumulation of fatigue does not by itself cause dissolution, but will increase the ethereal’s susceptibility to dissolution. An ethereal may possess a live body by winning a mental conflict with the resident Aura. Possession is easier if part of the native Aura is absent as an astral. A possessed body acquires the personality attributes of the invading spirit, while physical attributes are unchanged. All disembodied inidviduals have Telepathy and Sensitivity Psionic talents during their ethereal state. These talents are dormant in all creatures with Aura. Kethira, Yashain, and the Astral Planes all exist in the same or nearby physical space. Movement between these planes is almost instantaneous, assuming the traveler knows the paths to take which is never easy given the ever-shifting nature of the Astral planes. An ethereal move applies only to movement on the same plane. The risk of having a stranger establish squatter’s rights in the “temple of one’s body” is one of the greater hazards of astral travel. From an astral’s perspective, this is akin to breaking into someone’s house, eating the food, drinking the wine, trying on the clothes, beating the servants, and bedding the spouse. A vanquished native spirit may attempt to regain its own body with a new Mental Conflict after the normal period of Dissolution. An ongoing struggle between the invading and native spirit may cause further personality switches. Ethereals may also possess the body of a recently dead creature, thus creating a Zombie.

Each person has a soul, the non-physical portion of the person. When the body dies, the soul journeys to its afterlife. Most people commit their soul to one god who takes possession of the soul upon death. Those who die godless, or out of Divine Grace with their god, embark on a Death Journey unless “saved” by a funeral rite. All clerics are taught Passage of the Soul, a funeral ritual to help a soul make a swift journey to its afterlife. Although funerals vary from church to church and from region to region, the basic pattern is the same; a priest of shaman performs the ritual to get the attention of the god. Then the priest orchestrates a prayer (often sung) to confer a state of Divine Grace upon the deceased by gathering Piety from the attendees. Those who do not attain sufficient piety for Divine Grace are on their own as they make the Death-Journey.
Agrikans practice ritual cremation. Ashes are scattered outdoors or interred in temple vaults, depending on the importance of the deceased to the church.

Haleans practice mummification and lay their dead in elaborate tombs surrounded by their worldly goods. However, such rites must be paid for (lavishly). Haleans are cremated if they cannot afford the rituals.

Ilvirans desire to have their mortal remains taken to Araka-Kalai, but few followers are so honored. Most Ilvirans are quietly buried. Because of their belief in reincarnation, the internment occurs at dusk and the grave is unmarked.

Laranians abhor cremation. Wealthy families encrypt their dead in family vaults or communal temple vaults. Those who cannot afford this kind of treatment like to be buried on a battlefield, preferably one where they have fought.

Morgathians are the most sophisticated tomb builders on Lythia. They inter their dead in vast, extensive catacombs. In regions where the church is outlawed, covert temples to the Lord of the Undead have vaults where the Morgathian dead (and, it is said, undead) are laid.

Navehan clerics are rumored to eat their dead. Lay followers often practice ritual cremation, but other methods are sometimes used. The Navehans seem to have little reverence for their dead, reserving their respect for the shade of the deceased instead.
Peonianism is mainly a religion of rural folk. Burial is the common practice, and most Peonian graveyards are found adjacent to the parish church, or on a nearby hillside.

Sarajinians prefer cremation, or burial in stone crypts, a habit they probably acquired from the Khuzdul. In either case, they like a selection of their worldly goods to accompany them (it is no longer the practice for a warrior’s wives and thralls to accompany him). Wealthy Ivinians like to be buried in a boat, sometimes set ablaze, sometimes placed in a stone tomb.

Save-K’norans practice cremation. Their ashes are then placed in a small urn that is buried. A riddle or puzzle which reveals the location of the urn is engraved on a small memorial plaque, which is then incorporated into some stonework within a temple or its compound. Solving the riddle may find the mortal remains, and a trinket or two to encourage the game, but this obliges the finder to mention the deceased in the finder’s own “death-riddle.”

Siemians do not believe in using land for graves or memorials. The Sindarin cremate their dead and scatter the ashes in a forest. The Khuzan practice is to entomb their deceased in stone; but, if this is not practical, cremation is preferred to burial in earth.

The Death-Journey can be long and fraught with peril, depending upon how far a person is out of Divine Grace and is a series of encounters which continue until the unclaimed soul acquires sufficient piety for Divine Grace or until it is captured and taken to a deity. Each encounter automatically starts hostile, although it need not end that way, and a character might even gain an ally to escort him on his Death-Journey. Use the Mental Conflict rules to resolve encounters along the Death-Journey. If the individual defeats an ethereal of the same species, it can take possession of the physical body (if any) and end the Death-Journey.

Ghost: Souls that have not completed their Death-Journey. They may wait in one place performing what acts they can to build the Piety they need to make their journey. Ghosts may help or hinder the journeyer. The winner of any mental conflict steals of the loser’s piety. The conflict resolution separates the contestant on the Astral plane, so a repeated encounter is unlikely.

Demigod: A random servitor of one of the gods. The demigod will immediately engage in Mental Conflict. If successful, the demigod brings the lost soul to its master. If the random demigod is a servant of the lost soul’s deity, the soul is admitted to its afterlife.
Ilsiri: These spirits may help or hinder the journeyer, but their behavior is alien to humans. See Siem.
Ethereal Ivashu: Ilvir has some Ivashu that roam the ethereal world, gathering souls for use in his creations. They always engage in mental conflict.

Ethereal Humanoid: A human shaman or Shek-Pvar in an ethereal state. May help or hinder the journeyer. A Sindarin will always help journeyer, after an initial challenge or contest to test the mettle of the journey.

Spells and ritual invocations should never be confused. Clerics seek to draw the deity’s attention by performing a ritual, and encourage intervention by limiting the call to a specific effect but, ultimately, they depend on their deity to act. Spellcasting, on the other hand, involves powers released by a mage from the fundament of Kelestia and requires no divine intervention. Mages are generally offended by any suggestion that a spell is miraculous. Conversely, any claim that a ritual invocation is a spell would be construed by most clerics as an admission of blasphemy.

Ritual is a skill which reflects an individual’s knowledge of church dogma, holy scriptures, chants, songs, and mysteries. There is a separate Ritual Skill for each deity. It is used by clerics for performing ritual invocations. Individuals may, theoretically, have Ritual for two or more deities. Learning Rituals assumes the individual in question has received some basic instruction in the church mysteries and been baptized into the faith. Ritual Mastery can only be improved by learning new invocations, reading Holy Tomes, or performing an invocation in an adverse situation or in ritual church duty.

Ritual invocations are ceremonies that “encourage” a deity to intervene with a miracle. They originated as a means for clerics to impress their laity or potential converts. These uses are still practiced, but many invocations work equally well (often better) to subdue those who oppose a cleric’s deity. Such use is tacitly approved by all churches, since the “proxy wars” of mortals is an acceptable method of conflict among deities. Theoretically, anyone may learn the rituals of any Circle, but most churches will teach them only to ordained priests. The rituals were once closely associated with a specific circle, higher rituals being the exclusive knowledge of higher circles. They are still classified in this way, but “leakage” of knowledge over the centuries has eroded this restriction. Today, the invocations of any Circle can be taught to any ordained priest.
People may perform any invocation they know. Invocations can be learned in one of three ways: from a mentor, from holy scriptures, or by divine revelation.
Mentor training. Most invocations are learned from another cleric who knows it. Both the student and mentor must be fluent (★★★) in a shared language.

Holy Scriptures. There are a wide variety of holy writings, parables, songs, poems, and teachings that can be thought of as Holy Scriptures. Church archives are filled with such written works and clerics consult them to expand their knowledge of dogma and ritual. Invocations can be learned from Holy Scriptures if they are written in a known language and script, or a reliable translator must be available.

Divine Revelation. In rare cases, a deity may wish to provide knowledge of an invocation to any adherent, perhaps even a lay adherent. Such revelations are handled at GM discretion, but are only likely to occur if an individual succeeds on a Divine Intervention roll.
To learn an invocation, a person must spend 5 days per Circle. That is, for a III Circle invocation, a person spends 15 days. (The number of watches it takes is 45.)

It should not be assumed that clerics are the only people with access to ritual invocations. The Morgathian Prophet Balsha, for example, received no formal training in the tenets of the Morgathian Church, yet miracles were invoked in his presence. Most clerics feel a prophet appears when a church needs to be steered away from a path of action which does not please its deity. Of course, one person’s prophet is another person’s heretic.

Temples are always consecrated ground, and certain areas such as crypts and graveyards can be made holy to a specific deity by the ritual invocation Consecration. Peoni and Larani are allied and oppose Agrik. Morgath, the Lord of Chaos, opposes everyone, but can be, in some circumstances, “allied” with Agrik. All other gods are neutral, but tend to favor Peoni and Larani. An invocation call usually consists of a quick prayer or chant, but can involve (if time permits) construction of an altar, burning of incense, an appropriate sacrifice, etc. The intent is to perform a ritual which is less likely to annoy the deity. It is said the powers of Naveh and Morgath arise at night and slumber in the light, and those of Sarajin are highest amid ice and snow.
Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch.

Initiates a new convert, who must be willing, to the faith. The ceremony involves a laying on of hands and dabbing with Holy Water, or other consecrated substance. Takes 15 minutes and the convert may immediately gain piety unless he already was initiated, in which case it has no effect.
Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch/Sermon.

A ritual to bestow piety on the subject. The piety is transferred from the cleric to the subject(s). Blessing may (optionally) be used to neutralize the effect of a Hex Psionic talent or a Curse invocation. Takes 1 minute and grants ★ Piety improvement to all within hearing range except those performing the ritual. This additional Piety is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond a one star addition.
Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Self.

An attempt to establish a close spiritual relationship with the deity. The cleric hopes to earn the deity’s favor, reflected by receiving bonus Piety. Takes 1 minute and grants ★ Piety improvement to the caster. This additional Piety is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond a one star addition.
Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch.

An invocation to allow adherents of the same deity to voluntarily transfer piety to the invoker. The intent is to give the cleric more piety for any desired use. All donors of piety must touch the invoker. Takes 15 minutes and grants Piety. This additional Piety is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond one star.
Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch.

A marriage ceremony which typically lasts one hour. Both the groom and bride must be of the same religion, or one spouse must be baptized in the other’s faith before marriage. The ceremony blesses and awards to each spouse the chance to improve their piety from the deity, unless either is already married in that religion.
Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: N/A.

A funeral ceremony to aid a soul to make a quick and uneventful death journey. The intent is for the cleric and/or any attendees to give the departed sufficient piety to ensure Divine Grace. Individuals may give additional piety by special prayer, etc. This takes 15 minutes to perform and grants one departed soul ★ Piety improvement. Multiple castings have no further effect.
Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: 50 feet.

Creates a feeling of the presence of the deity. In crisis situations, the effect is to cause all persons within Range who are not adherents of the deity to suffer a few seconds of non-action immediately, effectively pausing. Any ongoing skill attempt without reasonable waypoints must be restarted. The invocation may be limited to specific individuals touched by the cleric. Both forms take 10s to perform.
Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: Self/Touch.

Takes 1 minute and grants ★ Stamina improvement to one subject (usually a friend) within Range. This additional Stamina is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond a one star addition.
Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: Self.
Allows the cleric to speak and understand any language. Takes 5 minutes and lasts for 30 minutes. This addition is lost like fatigue after that. No permanent learning enhancement.
Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: Earshot.

Allows the cleric to perceive a lie when talking with someone. Truthsense cannot force a person to speak to the cleric. Takes 1 minute to cast and then lasts for another 5 minutes. Effects the caster only and what he hears. Affects commission and omission lies in the same way.
Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Self.

One Question may be asked of the Deity. An attempt to discover the will of the deity. Some clerics prefer to Summon a divine servant of their deity and ask it questions with Divination. A summoned being can be asked three questions. Takes 5 minutes to enact (during which the questions must be posed). A minor wound of ★ levels is always received.
Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Earshot.

An attempt to invoke the displeasure of the cleric’s deity upon one named victim. Curses cannot kill nor be randomly directed. A curse is usually a short, simple declaration. The Medical/Psyche tables can help inspire effects to the caster. Takes 5 minutes to enact a penalty of ★. This penalty is lost like fatigue. Otherwise works as Psionics/Hex. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition/subtraction beyond one star. If hours are used instead of minutes, a random medical/psychic problem is created and the range is one league. The caster will receive a wound of the same level (including severity), which will heal normally.
Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: 50 yards.

Allows the cleric (only) to perceive all ethereal phenomena within Range as faint, colored lights for Duration. The Summoning invocation may be used on a revealed ethereal with a bonus of ★. The ritual may be enacted for as long as desired. Caster is at a penalty of ★ for everything that does not involve ethereals.
Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Unlimited.

Calls forth a specific denizen of the cleric’s deity. The more powerful the denizen, the more difficult it will be to summon. If the ethereal has already been perceived by the Revelation invocation, Summon Mastery is improved by ★. A summoned denizen will appear after the ritual is completed. It may be asked three questions with Divination, or banished with Command, etc. It takes 30 minutes to enact this ritual. The will of the ethereal is a penalty to the skill roll.
Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Earshot.

Cleric perceives the presence and location of any holy artifact within Range. The artifact emits an ultra-sonic hum audible only to the cleric. This takes 1 minute to give a preternatural hearing attribute for holy artifacts of ★★★★★, which will hum at ultra-sound at conversational volume. This attribute dies down as fatigue.
Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: 50 feet.

The ability to control/banish all divine servants within Range. Clerics can command only the servants of their own deity. Hostile servants of the cleric’s deity may be banished. Servants of other deities are not driven off, but will feel uncomfortable and, if not well-motivated to remain, probably leave anyway. Friendly servants may be commanded to perform one simple task. This takes 10s to enact. It affects only one servant at a time but the caster chooses which.
Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Touch.

A ritual to sanctify an object or place. Consecrations last indefinite and may be removed by another consecration, but with a special penalty of ★★, but for rituals of different deities this is at a penalty of ★★★★★ if the invoker is an adherent of another deity. Permanent consecrations can never be removed, except by physical destruction of the object.

Holy Water: consecrated water, used in several invocations. Three churches use other substances: Agrikans use ash; Haleans use perfumes; Morgathians use human blood. Each dose requires the ritual to be 5 minutes long; one charge is 3 ounces.

Holy Tome: a sacred written work which may grant the reader an increase to Ritual Mastery. These tomes have a star rating, each providing a more profound improvement chance for the Ritual skill mastery. Each volume requires the ritual to be 15 minutes long. Non-consecrated books do not grant immediate learning rolls.

Holy Artifact: a consecrated artifact, typically a staff, rod, ring, amulet, belt buckle, brooch, etc. Artifacts store a known invocation for instant activation on command. Cleric determines the number of charges to install – each charge takes a casting time of 5 minutes times the Circle. Hence, storing three charges of a Circle V invocation cost 3 x 5 x 5 = 75 minutes. Use of an artifact generally requires some sort of triggering or activation. Most often, this is done by speaking (or thinking of) a particular key word or phrase. Invoking the ritual requires comparing piety against 5 times the Circle embedded.

Holy Place: sanctifying a site to the deity, such as a temple, graveyard, site of a martyrdom, etc. The location may already have been sanctified to another deity. The casting time is 2 minutes for each square yard to be consecrated. The area to be consecrated must be walked upon during the ritual. Any version of the ritual must be completed within one watch.
Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Unlimited.

May only be performed on a subject of the same religion who has lesser rank and Circle. Strips the subject of rank and responsibilities within the church and notifies the deity that the subject is out of favor. Deity might not agree with the action and may, especially in cases of impiety or corruption, penalize the invoker instead. Circle reduction is as far as the caster is authorized to invoke by the church.
Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Touch.

Seeks to banish a possessing spirit from a victim. The ceremony requires frequent laying on of hands and Holy Water. The invocation involves Mental Conflict with the possessing spirit, modified by ★★. Casting time is 5 hours.
Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Self.

Allows the invoker’s soul to temporarily depart the body which is left in a state of metabolic suspension. The disembodied soul functions as an Astral Entity for Duration. This takes 10 minutes and lasts for 5 hours. At the end the pull-back is near instantaneous. Fatigue applies.

Physical conflict is an important aspect of Hârnic culture. The following compilation is an extract and modernization of the anonymous treatise The Colloquium of the Four Veterans. It is clear that the author must have witnessed several of the recent Hârnic wars and extensive knowledge of conflicts with barbarian tribes. Only the essence of this four volume treatise is captured here. It is treasured among scholars.

Weapon: Some weapons are restricted by region, race, and custom. (C) Chivalric (noble) Weapon; (T) Tool/Peasant weapon; (M) Also missile weapon, data given here is for use as Melee weapon, for use as Missile weapon see later; (R) Rare Weapon (on Hârn); (G) Gargun Weapon; (S) Sindarin Weapon; (L) Long Weapon. Attacks at 5 foot range and cannot Attack closer.
Skill: Combat Skill to use the weapon.
WT: Weight of the weapon in pounds. Trace items (arrows, slingstones, etc) are presumed to weigh 0.1 pounds each.

WQ: Weapons are rated for quality. Sturdy all-metal weapons like swords have higher ratings than hafted weapons like spears. WQ represents the chance a weapon breaks in certain combat situations. Higher quality weapons cost more.

HM: Hand Mode penalties. All weapons, except Bows and Blowguns, can be used one-handed. There is no bonus for two-handed use, but some weapons are penalized when used one-handed. Unless a person is ambidextrous, all weapons (except Shields) used in the secondary hand (left hand for most) also have a Hand Mode Special Penalty.

B/E/P: The impact (damage) of a weapon when it strikes. Weapons may have impact ratings for two or three Aspects: Blunt (B), Edge (E), and Point (P). A - rating indicates the weapon does not have this Aspect. A zero (0) rating means the weapon has the Aspect, but impact is +0. Point aspects in brackets are optional; if chosen, WQ is reduced by one (1). This is a “weapon-build” option.

Price: The retail price for average quality weapons. Higher quality weapons roughly double in price for each addition point in WQ. The source for weapons is a Weaponcrafter, except F (Fletcher), H (Hideworker), M (Metalsmith), or W (Woodcrafter). Individuals with related craft skills can make/repair their own weapons, but rarely with WQs as high as listed.

Armour can be defined as any article of clothing capable of reducing the damage done by weapon strikes. Even plain cloth can help to prevent a blade from cutting. Higher levels of armour protection cost significant amounts of money and the extra weight carried increases Encumbrance. The nature of this trade-off between armour types tends to reflect economic and technological realities, although cultural preferences are also a determinant. Some cultures favor heavy armour, others prefer light armour, and a few consider wearing any armour to be cowardly. Climate is also a consideration; wearing heavy, padded armours in a tropical climate is simply too exhausting to be practical. Different types of armour are usually worn in overlapping layers, such as Surcoat (cloth) over Mail over Quilt. The protective values of each layer are added together to determine total protection. Moreover, some body parts may benefit from two layers of the same material. For example, a warrior wearing a Mail hauberk and leggings, has double mail coverage for the Thigh, Groin, and Abdomen.

Combatants must find a balance between the protection offered by armour and the Encumbrance penalty it brings. Mail, Scale, and Plate armours are heavy. It may be tempting to wear multiple layers of Cloth or Quilt, but this is highly encumbering and especially fatiguing on a hot day. Each extra layer of Cloth or Quilt (except where they naturally occur from overlapping garments) incurrs a Special Penalty.

The table assumes average quality materials. Armour materials can be purchased at higher or lower qualities. The effect of these ratings (maximum +4) is to increase or decrease all protective values by the quality rating. That is, a +1 mail Hauberk has protective values of B3, E9, P6, and F2. No armour aspect can be reduced below one (1). Some Jmorvi Shek-Pvar with weaponcraft skill can produce enchanted armour. Such pieces are rare and have +1 quality per level of enchantment. To determine the quality for breakage, add all 4 protective values together through Row-5-Addition.
Cloth: heavy, coarse cloth, typically buckram or serge, worn over or under other types of armour, or alone as everyday garb. Fine linen clothing offers negligible armour protection.
Leather: soft leather or animal hide. Worn by itself, or as a base for Ring/Scale armours.
Quilt: two layers of cloth, stuffed with wool or straw, then stitched together. It is equivalent to Fur which some animals have as natural armour.
Kurbul: Azeryani name for thick leather hardened by boiling in wax or oil to produce a lightweight, resilient leather-plate for spot protection.
Ring: leather, reinforced by intermittent metal rings, strips, or studs.

Mail: butted, coiled, or riveted metal rings, linked together. Mail is lighter and more flexible than other metal armours, but is almost useless against Blunt and Fire strikes. Quilt is usually worn under Mail.
Scale: leather, reinforced by a continuous layer of thin, overlapping metal plates.
Plate: rigid, continuous, steel covering. Articulated, full-plate armour does not exist. Plate is expensive and is used mainly for helms and spot protection.
Joust*: These are regular items used in jousting context.
Items: Cloth and Quilt items are made by clothiers, leather by hideworkers, and all other items by weaponcrafters.
WT: Armour weight (lbs) for an average sized person.
Price: Typical retail selling price for an item of average size and quality.

div.p: Strike location is important for two main reasons. First, only the armour worn at the location struck is relevant. Second, injury effects vary by location; a blow to the skull is more serious than a blow to the foot. The percentages allocated to body parts do not reflect the relative size of that part, since the head, arms, or groin are favored targets. Combatants can influence Strike Location by targeting their aim. Although combatants instinctively turn to face the most imminent threat, some armour only covers part of a strike location - a breastplate, for example, only covers the front of the thorax and abdomen. In random situation, where it is hard to determine whether the front or back of a strike location is struck, experience shows there is a 75% chance of being struck on the front side. An asterisk (*) indicates that Stumble or Fumbles may apply.
The accuracy and impact of missile weapons depends on missile type and range. These effects are noted on the table.

Actions will take their time as desired and will be resolved accordingly. There is also no initiative, simply aborted actions, incomplete actions and action being affected by other activity. Some of the more common actions are listed.

Rest: The combatant does nothing except possibly sit or lie down. Resting combatants can attend to wounds, do minor weapon repairs, etc., and may defend normally if attacked later in a future second (and aware of the attack). Any resting action is then aborted.

Move: Unless physically hindered by obstacles or otherwise restrained, this option can take an arbitrary amount of time. The maximum speed is given by Agility. If the combatant enters an enemy Engagement Zone, he may be attacked. In the course of a Move, combatants may (within reason) change weapons, pick things up, etc. This will be deducted from their speed or time spent moving.

Engage: Combat involves footwork. Once a combatant lays “claim” to a certain spot, it is assumed that he moves about that point, without losing essential contact to adjacent combatants. This is called engagement and all engaged combatants are assumed to be able to move about as driven by necessity. If for some reason this engagement cannot be upheld, penalties apply, either to attack or defense. Disengage is a voluntary move out of the engagement zone of another combatant. This other combatant may choose to follow the disengaging combatant and thereby keeping him in the engagement zone. This voluntary footwork footwork has no penalties.

Charge: At the end of a fast move an attack usually gains a bonus. With steed, a Canter or Gallop move is needed. Note the stopping impacts; Stumbles and Unhorsing may apply. Also consider any collateral damage in the path of the charge. These may bring the speed down. At the end of the charge the steed may still be moving. Otherwise, the steed halts, which could leave the rider and steed in the middle of a somewhat hostile crowd. To continue charging, the weapon must be readied again, which can be handled as a grope action. Cavalrymen do not risk their extremely valuable horses galloping over battlefields, which are usually well supplied with furrows, rabbit holes, man-made pits, and caltrops. Galloping normally occurs only on good roads. A cavalry “charge” is mostly trotting into position, with perhaps twenty to sixty yards of canter at the end. Horses are extremely reluctant to charge into each other. Unless both steeds are separated by a short wall, they will veer apart beyond the range of most melee weapons. Charges against mounted opponents are rare except in organized tournaments.

Push: A combatant may intend to push another back without grappling him or charging into him. When this is intended during an attack. Opposed Push moves may cancel out. (This is different from ramming, which is resolved as a collision, see mounted combat, which may also be applied to humans, particularly those that intend to use their weight “benefit”.) Consider walls and ledges. Moving over a ledge may not be preventable, but moving into a wall generally is.

Rise: When a combatant stumbles (falls prone) he may try to get up; Acrobatics/Tumbling skills apply. The action is always successful unless the combatant is forcibly held down, suffering from a serious or grievous wound, etc.

Grope: Any action taken in Combat which requires manual dexterity, but is not an attack. For example, an attempt to draw or change weapons, string a bow, or retrieve an item from the ground are Grope actions. A Grope is automatically successful unless the combatant is forcibly held down, suffering from a serious or grievous wound, currently engaged, etc. Legerdemain applies. During a Grope, the combatant is considered prone.

Melee Attack: An effort to strike one engaged enemy with a melee weapon. Engaged combatants can move about as stated in Engagement. Melee Attacks generally take time, looking for an opening, sequencing weapon clashes, etc., before the weapon eventually strikes. Melee Attacks with bows or generally with a missile weapon is possible. A Shortbow, Hartbow, or Blowgun is treated as a stick, a Longbow as a staff, a Crossbow as a club, etc.

Missile Attack: Unprepared missile weapons (unstrung, packed, etc.) must be prepared by means of a Grope (above) and cannot be used until then. Assuming a prepared missile or throwing weapon is available, a combatant has one of two options: [1] Fire, which takes two seconds for any weapon, or [2] Load, which takes two (2) seconds for arrows and sling stones, but 10 seconds for a crossbow. A Rider Attack may also occur during a Mounted Move. Rider attacks are resolved normally. A lance may attack anything within 5 feet, but a 3-foot long sword or mace held in the right hand has restrictions. Discretionary Aiming Zone modifiers for the rider and warrior afoot may apply.

Grapple Attack: Any attempt to grapple, hold, or wrestle with one engaged opponent using Unarmed Combat. The Attacker must move into the location of the opponent, which is without penalty. The attacker attempts to impair the usage of limbs (or weapons) without causing fatigue or injury. If the grappler achieves any “Strike” result, a hold on the opponent has been gained. Determine Strike Location normally. The entire zone (Head, Body, Arms, or Legs) is considered tangled, but with arms and legs, left and right should be distinguished. The attacker's a weapon (e.g. his arm/hand) becomes entangled to maintain a hold/entanglement on the opponent. The attacker can release his hold any time (if the weapon was a net, a successful grope action is applicable). The wound level implied by the weapon is treated as penalty to any fumble or stumble rolls. Tangle/Grapple penalties apply until cleared by a successful Grope for weapons or grapple for maintained holds; tangled weapons may be dropped to escape the effect of the tangle.

Grapple Defense: An attempt to escape the hold of an attacker. The defender tests his unarmed combat to reduces his hold penalties accordingly. Of course, the defender may instead attempt to grapple the attacker himself.

Esoteric Attack/Defense: This option is available to combatants capable of using magic, or psionics, or able to call for divine intervention. an esoteric option may not be available to engaged combatants. an esoteric option that fails may have misfire results that affect both defender and attacker.
Dropping Items: Items may normally be freely discarded without resorting to a Grope. However, dropping an item which is tied on requires a Grope action.

Tangle Attacks: Certain weapons have the ability to tangle an opponent or the opponent’s weapons. Some weapons, such as the net, are designed specifically for this purpose. Tangle attacks may be attempted with cloaks, blankets, nets, flails, whips, ropes, or other items. If the tangle (or any other attack!) is aimed at a weapon, one Main location is replaced with the weapon, usually the leg of the “other” side. A tangle attack is treated as a melee attack (or missile attack if the tangle weapon is thrown).

Block/Dodge: An attempt to block, parry, or dodge the attack with a declared weapon (if available), usually a shield, although any held weapon, including a hand/arm, may be used. The defender must be aware of the attack.
Ignore: This option is normally taken only by combatants who are unaware of the attack (or objects). This may result from extreme surprise or from the Defender being physically incapable of defense.
Mount/Dismount: Mount or dismount in combat. Consider this a climb of five (5) feet but use Riding skill to determine speed. (Obviously, a grappling hook does not grant a bonus, but stirrup do.)

Mounted Move: A Mounted Move is made on part of the horse, the rider may act separately. Be aware that horses as large quadrupeds are more easily cornered or hindered in movement than medium bipeds such as humans.

Steed Trample: An attack by the Steed, commanded by the Rider. The defender may be located in a 5 foot radius around the steed - horses can wheel and kick in any direction (especially backwards) with great force. Steed Trample may be quite useful, if the rider is injured, or has dropped a weapon. A steed trample is like a Melee Attack.

Polearm Defense: Steeds have great difficulty committing suicide. Faced with a wall of sharp spears or stakes they generally balk and refuse to proceed. This survival instinct can only be overcome at great risk to the rider. The rider must make a special Steed Command Check with a ★.★. penalty. If the steed command fails, the steed makes an emergency stop, bucks, then flees.

Weather: Wind, rain/snow, mist/fog all have an effect on missile accuracy, especially at longer ranges. Wet bowstrings lose their tautness and are easily ruined if the bow is strung. When rain strikes, professional archers commonly unstring their bow and keep the bow string dry by storing it under their helmet. But if an archer does not mind risking a bowstring, a bow can be fired during a rainstorm. Bowstrings have a WQ of 8. There is also a Weather penalty on the archer to reflect reduced visibility in rain. Very cold (wooden) bows often shatter when drawn. If the air temperature is freezing, archers who attempt to fire their bow sometimes see that their bow breaks when drawn.

Ammunition: Combatants equipped with a Javelin or Shorkana may carry two or three (each is listed as a separate weapon). Most archers carry 12–24 arrows/quarrels, an extra bow, and three bowstrings for each bow. Assuming there is a plentiful supply of stones, ammo for Slings and Staff Slings can be ignored.

Close Mode: Some weapons, especially swung weapons, are difficult to use in restricted space. A Battlesword, for example, is superior to a Shortsword when fighting outdoors; but, in a narrow passageway or crowded melee, may be at a disadvantage. Generally, any thrusting weapon (such as a Spear, or a Sword employing Point aspect) has no disadvantages. Close Mode never penalizes Shields.

Target Shooting: Archery contests are popular at all fairs. In such contests, the target is generally set up at 100 yards range. It has a bull worth five points, then three concentric rings valued at three, two, and one point. The size is 3 feet. The intended wound level is ★. Hitting the target is 0, hitting the inner ring is ★ and hitting the bull is ★★.

Warhorses: The relationship between a warhorse and its rider is profound, almost telepathic in its depth of communication. It takes years to forge and is not lightly undertaken. A knight found weeping on the battlefield is as likely grieving over a fallen horse as a dead comrade. The best warhorses require extensive bonding and patient training. Horses are not seriously ridden until they are two years old, and very few are combat trained before age three. Although horses do not have the capacity for language, they can be trained to respond to verbal commands. Several cultures breed ponies for war, notably the Chelni and Hodiri tribal nations of Hârn.

Steeds: Steed quality is largely measured by Steed Morale, although other attributes such as Strength and Move are also important considerations when judging a horse. The principal effect of combat training is to increase Steed Morale, but Trample Mastery can also be improved. Steed combat training is undertaken by the rider. The rider must invest in the development of his horse as in his own. Steed Morale is reduced by ★★, when a steed has a different rider/trainer. This becomes a permanent reduction if the new rider is the new owner. The loss can recovered through training with the new owner.

Barding: Horse armour is rare on Hârn, partly due to high cost, partly because the protection gained does not justify the encumbrance. A Thorax strike has a chance of striking the saddle and/or saddle blanket. The occasional chanfron (Plate covering the horse’s Skull and Face (except eyes & muzzle) weight 20 lb, cost 500d+) is seen on the steeds of rich knights. Some very rich knights defy convention and armour their horses as a status symbol, but rarely fight that way.

Afoot versus Mounted: A combatant afoot may attack the rider or the steed normally. Aiming Zones may be limited. The rider may defend normally. The same is true in reverse and depends on the length of the weapon in both cases. Warhorses are valuable booty and can usually be ransomed or sold. Many knights consider it immoral to attack horses, although footmen about to be trampled are less reluctant.

Riderless Horses: When a horse finds itself without a rider, it will either stand in place or wander off. Test Steed Morale: On success, the steed stays with its rider, on failure, it wanders off. The rate of departure for a fleeing steed is generally a canter.

A battle is a noisy, confusing, scary place. The clash of arms, shouting, screaming (often some whimpering and dull thudding) can make it difficult to hear commands and cries for help. For this reason combatants do not always do what their superiors want them to do. Battle experience, discipline, and morale are three ambiguous, but important, elements in any battle. All these factors are accounted for by Morale, which benefits individuals with high Morale and is detrimental to combatants with low Morale. Having been prone in a Combat situation applies a penalty of ★★ to Horse Morale, which fades away.
Normal: A combatant with normal morale behaves without constraint, selecting and executing any reasonable action option.
Cautious: A cautious combatant will not Engage, must choose Pass if engaged, and will not Counterstrike.

Desperate: Combatant tries to conclude the battle, one way or the other, as soon as possible. Until the situation changes and a new Morale Test is passed, the combatant selects the most aggressive option available.

Broken: The individual is unable to fight in any useful way. The only available options are flight or surrender. Flight is normally preferable; surrender is a last resort. If neither is feasible, the individual makes a Rest or Pass action option, but can defend if attacked except that Counterstrike is prohibited.

Rally: The individual has enough combatant to support others in their Morale. He may provide his success to Morale rolls of others he can communicate with. This is valid for a synchronous Morale roll only. This may be augmented by Rhetoric.

Berserk: This is a special state of battle-frenzy. Any combatant who enters this mode will take the most aggressive action available for Attack or Defense, adding ★ to Attack Mastery subtracting ★ from Mastery to defend. Further Morale rolls are ignored until the battle ends. Some combatants may have a cultural heritage of berserking, or a particular reason to go berserk.

Combatants who sustain Serious or Grievous wounds may die during the healing routine. On the other hand, various types of magic, miracles, Psionics, and potions can improve healing. The following wound types exist and individual wounds are tracked with their location. Effects on the use of the corresponding part are described below.
★: Minor. Wounds only have wound penalty.

★★: Serious. Wounds of this type also have minor effects on neighbouring detailed body parts at ★ less. Any activity involving these body parts are at the appropriate penalty. These “effect” wounds do not heal separately.

★★★: Grievous. The detailed body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring detailed body parts, and minor on main parts. These “effect” wounds do not heal separately. Minor effects are at ★★ less than the Grievous, while serious are ★ less.

★★★★: Incapacitating, the main body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For head this means unconsciousness and for thorax imminent death.) Serious effects are at ★★ less than the Incapacitating.

★★★★★: Destroyed, the main body part lost its integrity, Grievous use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For limbs this means at least severed. Thorax is split open or spinal cord severed. For all but the extremities this means instant death. For all other body parts, death is probably imminent due to the side effects.) Grievous use effects are at ★★ less than the Destroyed.

Fumble/Stumble: A wound level ★ above Dexterity on an arm causes any object held to be dropped, a Fumble. A wound level ★ above Agility on a leg causes the victim to fall down, a Stumble. A combatant with wound level of less than ★★ above Dexterity is eligible for a Grope action to pick up any object dropped. A combatant that dropped to a Stumble but with a wound less than ★★ above Agility is likewise able to get back up. If the wound level exceeds these ★★ the pain and structural damage preclude recovery.

Any wound needs to heal its injury points. This depends on Stamina; medicine may improve the healing rate. A physician may attempt to find or create the correct medicine but his skill does not add to the healing directly. A serious wound may become infected until it turns into a minor wound. An infection is a daily attack on the wounded area with a level of the wound, defended against with Stamina. Medicine applies in the same way as for minor wounds, but it harder to obtain. A penalty of ★ is suitable. Any injury points gained through the infection is added to the original wound. This may turn the wound into a grievous wound. A grievous wound is a bleeder or otherwise makes the body lose vital fluids. Bloodloss is treated as a separate injury. Note that the circulatory system is incapacitated with points in excess of ★★★ as other body parts are. The circulatory system itself will not turn infectious. Treatment by physicians depend on the location. Some locations are incurable by Hârnic physicians. For multiple bleeders only take the maximum in the same extremity, but add those for different extremities. Incapacitating and destroying wounds have no additional effects over the bleeder and infection dangers.

The healing routine assumes a combatant will mainly be resting during the healing process. If a combatant gets involved in unreasonable physical exertion during Healing, the days of rest accumulated since the last day are forfeit; wounds are often aggravated or reopened by premature activity. Injury and Encumbrance penalties are ignored during Healing. Fatigue penalty (if any) are applied – injured combatants are supposed to get lots of rest.

The standard treatments mostly known by all still need to be applied and detailed, so a physician's diagnosis is always necessary. “Destroyed” wounds may be treated as incapacitating, with a Bonus on Diagnosis of ★. Note that the usage effects on bordering regions needs to be treated as well.

Fire and internal system damage is treated as frost, but some treatments may not be applied, because they will kill the patient. I.e. cleaning and dressing an internal organ is not possible for Hârnic medicine. A secondary treatment to sterilize and seal a Minor or Serious wound is Cauterization. It cannot be used on Grievous or worse wounds. The procedure is done after a wound’s treatment has been established by the normal treatment rules. A metallic object and fire are required. Cauterization is attempted at Physician Mastery add ★. The effect is to close the wound and modify the Healing Rate a second time. Cauterization cannot be undone or re-attempted. It always leaves a nasty, broad scare and Comeliness effects may be applicable. Amputations and immediate cauterizations stop infections.

Diseases and Toxins come in various forms. All of the below characteristics are subject to improvements by a knowledgeable physician. Some poisons and ailments may be subject to infections. Deterioration: This is the speed at which wound points are accrued. This can be modified by Stamina. Maximum Injury: The maximum amount of injury the wound will cause, after deterioration has set in. Note that healing may prevent the maximum to actually be reached. Heal time: This is the speed at which wound points are reduced. Assume this to set in at the same time deterioration sets in.

Jousting is a formalized style of combat between two mounted contestants, whose object is to charge and strike the opponent with a couched lance. It is seen at most Hârnic tournaments. The rules for winning vary, but the most common set is known as the Laranian Joust. This contest is won by the first jouster to accumulate three (3) points. Breaking a jousting pole against an opponent counts as one (1) point and unhorsing an opponent counts as three (3) points. Striking any part of the saddle scores no points and striking a steed (causing injury) is automatic disqualification. The jousters are permitted to make no more than three passes in a bout. If, after three tilts, the score remains tied, or if both knights are simultaneously unhorsed, the combatants fight on foot using (real) swords or maces. The first knight to strike his opponent three times is the winner, except strikes to the shield do not count.

Jousts require the use of jousting poles, which are a specialty of polearm. These are listed on the Weapon Data Table. Compared to a regular Lance, Jousting Poles are much longer (typically 15feet), more fragile (they are intended to break on impact), and the tip is padded or fitted with a coronel to prevent the weapon from piercing armour. The price (40d) assumes the jousting pole is painted and fitted with a coronel and vamplate. A plain wooden jousting pole costs only 24d. At Laranian tournaments jousting poles are fitted with a flared metal vamplate to protect (B6 E10 P6 F2) the right hand.

Jousters wear the same armour in the Joust as they would in war – only more if possible. While there is nothing in the way of specialized armour for the Joust, most participants wear great helms and additional protection to the torso, such as a Kurbul breastplate. At most tournaments, jousters are required to wear a linen Surcoat showing their heraldic device. Some jousters, particularly the wealthy ones, attempt to stand out by wearing (sometimes outlandish) crests on their helms and Ailettes on their shoulders displaying their heraldry. Knights may also cover their steeds with a caparison that displays heraldic colors and device. Caparisons typically weigh about 30lb and cost at least 240d, often a lot more depending on materials and design.

Jousting is used to settle affairs of honor among nobles (dueling). If both participants and the organizer agree, more lethal, regular lances may be used. It is accepted that those too old or infirm to joust, or those of high station, may appoint a champion to joust for them, even in duels of honor. The privilege of a lady’s favor may be granted to a noble knight. The value of such a token is purely symbolic, a romantic epitome of the chivalric ethos. The nature of the favor can have complex symbolism of its own. A scarf or kerchief is a neutral item, a garter or lock of hair may not be. Some favors are displayed publicly; some are not.

Jousting is simultaneous combat. The two combatants spur their horses to charge, and then attack each other as they pass. Riding skill has an effect on the jouster’s combat. Each jouster makes a Steed Command check to begin the charge.
